content:
Posted: February 5, 2015
												Torchlight 2 Review:For this review I will make an effort to break down and analyze different major aspects of the game.1: Story2: Graphics3. A: GamePlay Mechanics3  B: Classes3 C: Loot/Equipment4: Wrap up and Bonus1 StoryThe Setting of the game takes place directly after the events of torchlight 1, the alchemist has broken out of the ember mine that the entirety of Torchlight 1 has taken place in, and you start your character out just outside a major town that he has already been through.The vast majority of the Game's story is presented to you through dialogs with the various NPCs that inhabit the area. The actual story itself, in my opinion is nothing special and while they did make a decent effort, ultimately it falls short of really sucking me in. (But lets be honest the story isn't why you play the game is it?) having said that I did appreciate the easter eggs that the developers put in including a reference to a very popular game that came out around the same time that has the same basic formula. 2. GraphicsThe game has a bright and colorful world with matching art direction. All the creatures, NPCs and classes look great, a refreshing break from the bleak and demonic tropes that are prevelent throughout the genre. The Spell effects are cool and they don't generally get in the way of seeing the monsters and such.  Since the game has lower system requirements than Diablo 3, and starts out in a lower price point,  the equipment and overall graphics aren't quite as impressive as Diablo 3. But, the graphics overall feel more like diablo 2 than diablo 3 does. 3 A. GamePlay MechanicsThe Combat is fun and depending on the difficulty, requires a lot of careful consideration on how you build and equip your character. I love it. In many ways, I am reminded of diablo 2 in how the mechanics are structured. Its not quite as deep as diablo 3, but I was not expecting that much.  Movement is fluid, and, thanks to the low system requirements it runs at a solid 60FPS on my iMac from 2010. You have 2 different types of leveling you can do. You can Level up traditionally from gettinng experience which allows you to distribute 5 stat points to whatever you want (instead of them automatically being distributed in diablo 3)3 B: ClassesThe Vanilla game comes with 4 classes, each look and feel completely different from each other. The Embermage starts out weaker than others, but as you unlock new skills you find yourself with a huge grin on your face as you wipe out legions of enemies. Just don't expect to be able to take more than a few hits.  While with the berzerker you go right up close and personal to the enemies attack quickly and annihilate them. The engineer plays more like a tank, with slow deliberate attacks and skills that allow you to summon helpers to attack enemies or to distract enemies from you. Finally, the Marksman focuses on hit and run from  a-far  with skills that allow for those types of tactics. Natually each of the characters has many skills to choose from that allow for alternate tactics. Unlike Diablo 3, or Path of Exile once you choose a skill, you have to pay to reroll the skills up to 3 previous skill points can be refunded.3 C: Loot/Equipment  The loot and equipment is quite similar to other games in the genre (IE diablo clones), with the standard tropes of rarity (IE normal, magic, rare and unique, and legendary) with increasing number of bonus' to stats depending on rarity. Each Class has two types of unique weaponry, however that doesn't mean you can't equip melee weapons on a mage or on a ranged character.4. Wrap up:I was excited for it because several former developers of diablo 2 were heading up this team. I have played a large amount of the game under VMware while I was waiting for the mac native version. and its safe to say that I've gotten my money, your money, and two other people's money's worth out of the game.The thing that REALLY sold it to me was the Mod Support.5: Mods! Well you've beaten the vanilla game, thats all well and good but are you ready for the REAL fun to begin? download the Synergies Mod. What does it do? Well for starters, it adds 3 new classes, that all feel  like they belong in the game nearly 700!! new pieces of equipment and weapons, new areas to explore, new enemy types, an end-game and raids. not to mention a rebalancing of the existing skills and classes. I would say that its got more content in it than most expansions's do. I cannot reccomend this mod enough. Unfortunately, there is a maximum of 10 mods per game. (this is gotten around by combining mods into 1 large mod pack) And you cannot play with those who do not have the same mods as you. 6. RatingIn this rating system 5 is average,  which means its plenty good just nothing special, even slightly. NOTE the scores below are weighted against other games in the genre.Story: 3/10 There is a story, it ends and has no plot holes. But thats about it.Graphics: 5/10 While its not super fancy and flashy like its bigger budget siblings, the art direction is pretty good and ages wellMechanics 7/10 Again, not as deep as bigger budget entries in the genre but still plenty of fun (and mod support really helps with this aspect)Sound: 8/10 Matt Uleman (the composer of the dIablo 1 and 2 soundtrack) did the soundtrack for this game and you can hear echos of his earlier work, and its glorious.Combat: 5  out of 10 Its not great but it sure is quite a satisfying experience overall.

content:
Posted: December 30, 2013
												Game: Torchlight 2Genre: RPG-AdventureDeveloper: Runic GamesSystem: PC (Steam)Total Score: 92/100Value Score: 9.2/10• Story: 7/10o Torchlight 2's storyline picks off where Torchlight 1 ended. The Alchemist which was one of the main characters from the first game ended up becoming corrupt thanks to the effects of the last game's villain's heart. Now you who will play as a new character will have to hunt him down and save the world from whatever he is planning to. You'll be going through several towns, dungeons and all sorts of terrain to find the Alchemist. The storyline overall is a bit generic but the side stories and side quests and their importance plays a interesting role within the overall game.• Characters: 7/10o Characters from the first game do appear in this game but barely do you interact with them, other than that all the enemies in the game and the characters you meet afterwards are all new but do not hold much substance like other RPGs however the amount of characters especially when it comes to enemy designs is quite huge. The player themselves can also create their own character, choosing the gender, skin color, hair appearance and color amongst other tidbits though you would not probably notice a difference due to the fact the armor you get in the game would make it to where you probably would not care about how you make your character look.• GamePlay: 10/10o Torchlight 2's gameplay is very similar to Torchlight 1's with a few new additions. For one, you have the choice to play as 4 different classes: Berserker which is best for close quarters combat and has insane speed, Mechanic is which best as a support character and as a secondary attacker, Outlander which is best with long range attacks and finally Ember Mage which is the equivalent of a Wizard in TL2 which is pretty much self explanatory. Depending on what you choose for skills and equipment you can build your character up to different builds and uses such as having a offensive ember mage instead of a magic user. The user interface is very similar to TL1 which is heavily inspired by Diablo and World of Warcraft. You have access to different features in towns and throughout different dungeons such as the ability to gamble for items, power up items through enchantments (which do not break or de-enchant anymore), to fuse items. Along with that the usual item shop, weapon/armor shop, and the special item/magic shop as well. There are a lot of side quests along with the story's main quests. One of the biggest additions to the game from its predecessor is Online Multiplayer, many people have anticipated this feature and wanted so much from the first game will now get to enjoy it in this game as up to 6 players can connect to each other on TL2's public servers or make their own private server via LAN. All items are exclusive to each player, no player will see another player's item or treasure (this is to prevent any disputes for loot).• Graphics: 10/10o Torchlight 2's graphical interfaces, environment and character sprites designs are similar to the first game but further improved with using current technologies making it one of the best looking 2Dish helicopter view games ever made.• Sound: 10/10o Torchlight 2 uses voiceovers throughout the majority of the game's main storyline, there will be instances where you will hear voices from other npcs and from yourself during dungeon raids. Torchlight 2's sound effects are both a combination of new effects to the game and uses some effects from the first game. The voiceovers are pretty well done for the characters and the sound effects go nicely with the environment and during the action sequences of cutscenes and battles.• Music: 8/10o Torchlight 2 uses similar style of music that the first game used, calm soothing orchestral type music is used mostly in the game, most of the parts of the game it has that unique Star Wars like epic feeling in the background whenever you travel the terrain or go through a town conversing with the NPCs. The developers were also kind enough to allow players to actually have access to the full OST of the game via the Game's folder on the PC, so enjoy the whole OST of Torchlight 2 on your portable mp3 player.• Length: 10/10o Torchlight 2's length is possibly its second greatest aspect if not the gameplay, the game's main storyline by itself should take you no more than 20 hours and additional 5-10 hours' worth of grinding and side questing on the side. If that isnt enough, you may do multiple playthroughs with friends or with other characters to see the world of Torchlight through different experiences which of course adds massive appealing value to this aspect.• Replay Value: 10/10o One of the best things about most western games is the replay value and TL2 is no exception. The Online multiplayer experience by itself adds great value to the replay value through different experiences and difficulties available for you to choose from. Once you finish the game, you get access to a endless random dungeon which takes you to random environments so you can explore thoroughly for additional treasures and other items. Along with that to add even more value, they added a New Game+ which allows you to play the game all over again using the same character but with a more difficulty twist to the gameplay.• Player Value: 10/10o Overall Torchlight 2 expands over the first one and improves in pretty much in every way, despite some network issues it may have from time to time, players will surely enjoy the multiplayer experiences and if not they can dabble on the single player experience which like the multiplayer can be experienced through different difficulties. You have a pretty decent customization options for your characters and can easily build up any class in any possible way. The graphical details have improved from the game, the sound effects and music are kept the similar to the first game. Pretty much TL2 consists of all the good aspects of TL1 plus more.

												Fishing Simulator Steam Sale 2016I wanted to have my first review for something I could write fairly, not too biased, not too unknowing. Torchlight II I think fits this description.There are a few cons to Torchlight II, but they do get overthrown fairly easily with this game. So let's start with the bad.|Cons|Bugs - Yes, bugs. Not the ones you'll be killing in game or transforming your pet into either. For how long this game has been out, I was surprised to have an almost game breaking bug happen in multiplayer whenever I levelled up. My partner I was playing with would be disconnected whenever I would level. This happened for about 25 levels in game. If became a joke about having to save a million times as I was getting closer to leveling up, but it was still extremely annoying. It could've been a mod we have installed, but it has since fixed itself and said mod is still there and hasn't been updated. Pet AI - Not the greatest thing sometimes. Many times have I had a pet get stuck in a corner and not be able to move until I go back and essentially force him to move the opposite direction and then slowly walk around the corner it was getting stuck on. This doesn't happen often, but it still is a bit annoying.Fishing Time - However much I love the fishing, I hate how sometimes I can catch one in less than 3 seconds and other times I have to wait almost 20 for the circle to go grey. It adds a bit to the immersion of fish don't all bite immediately or the same, but it's still a bit of a hassle sometimes, especially to get that covetted cheevo of fishing 1000 times. Voices - I can honestly say, I don't know much about the story of the game because I can't be bothered listening to the bad voice actors of the game. Yes I can read the story, but it's more fun to just click and get back to hitting things with my sword. Truth be told though, I have a really hard time sitting there reading something when they just add massive reverb to everybody important to make them sound like a ghost or the lack of enthusiasm in most of the character's voices. Now for what we really came here for... the good stuff...|Pros|Multiplayer - Yes, it sounds crazy, a dungeon crawler Diabloesque game without multiplayer? It happened... before I bought it... hence why I have it now and not then. Great game to play multiplayer. Loot System - If you're like me and don't like playing single player with dungeon crawler games, then you'll love the loot system. No dashing in to steal everything and then break friendships for life because you Tanked and did all the damage to said boss and friend runs in and grabs your legendary class drop and wont give it to you... FML for all the times that happened. Instead, everybody has their own loot drops. Wonderful system to have and keeping friends together since 2012.Pets - Although the pet AI can stink sometimes, it's great having something to kill with. Great for tanking or ranged DPS, pets can do almost anything you can. Seriously, you can even give them spells that they can cast. It's great. There's a huge variety you can "transform" them into as well for times ranging from 5 minutes to inifite. Fishing - Again, I had my hate on for fishing earlier, but only because I have done it so much and spent hours into just sitting there in town and doing the nasty... gutting a half dead fish. 60+ bucks to sell in store or great buffs for you. Can even have your pets transform from them. Giants are a pain to get, only about 1 in 150 fishing, but still great.Mods - THANK GAWD for mods. Makes the game greater than it already is. Not as many as I would like to see, but still a great amount. It's awesome seeing a modding community that's still active with a 4 year old game (at time of posting this review... 2016).|Final Thoughts|This is the game I feel Diablo should try to take over and implement into their already decent system. It's brighter than Diablo, but I think that goes without saying. This is a great game overall and even better with friends. Do I recommend buying it for CAD $21.99? If you have a friend to play with, then yes. If you're alone, I would wait until this puppy goes on sale.|Final Score|Graphics 8.5/10Stability 6/10Sound 9/10Voices 4/10Replay Value 9.5/10Fun 9/10Overall With Voices 7.5/10True Overall 8.5/1010/10 Would fish again

content:
Posted: May 22, 2014
												I remember the day when I had bought this game when it was on a Steam sale. I had a couple of dollars left and I wanted to spend the money on something that interested me. I had bought Torchlight II and haven't touched it for quite some time, since I was not an active Steam user back then. When I first played it, I immediately regretted not playing this sooner.Torchlight II is, to put in the simplest words, an amazing game. The product is a highly polished game with many surprises hidden around every corner.  The world is randomly generated every time you start a new character/start New Game+ on an existing character so every experience will be a highly unique one. The game really gets to the point; you can immediately delve into the fun of clicking on monsters and annihilating them with your weapons/skills.As is said in many other reviews, the story is definitely lacking. I had attempted to follow the story when I first started playing but ended up not caring for the story at all. If you are into an RPG with a rich story, this game is not for you.Gameplay-wise, this game tops it all. You'll be mashing your number hotkeys and your mouse trying to rid of the monsters trying to swarm you. There are many random traps and surprises lurking in every dungeon and area you face. The skills for each character are also special and will leave you wanting to upgrade all your skills. As said before, each dungeon and area is randomly generated, providing a unique experience everytime you play. You will feel a great sense of accomplishment as you finally knock out the final boss of the game. This then leads to the Mapworks, which you can buy with your in-game currency and play special dungeons. Or you can start up NG+ and start your whole adventure again, keep all your character stats but buffing all item drops and monsters.All in all, Torchlight II is definitely a game that anyone should check out, even if you do not like RPGs. This game is a must-have on anyone's game list.

content:
Posted: December 1, 2013
												I've never been a hard-core fan of this type of games. Sure, I liked playing Diablo for a while (can't even remember if it was the first or the second on the series), but nothing more than that. When Diablo 3 came out, I saw the game and couldn't really figure out what all the fuss was about. Sure, the game looked good, but nothing more. So when a friend tried to convince me to get both the Torchlight games (I & II), I politely dismissed the idea and moved on, thinking that if Diablo 3 didn't get me excited, no other similar games would either. It took me a while to change my mind and try Torchlight 1. Didn't like it much, I suppose because it was already a while after its expiry date for new players. After another cooldown period, I decided I'd give this series another chance, this time with the newer and shinier sequel. I suppose it's pretty obvious by now, that this is where I got pulled in. While I can't compare Torchlight II to Diablo 3 (mainly because I haven't given Diablo 3 a decent chance), I can say that by itself, Torchlight II is a lot of fun to play. The graphics are cool, the animations are clean and smooth, the story and quests are interesting and the controls are very easy and intuitive.The only drawback this game has, in my opinion, is the tedious gear system. While I do enjoy the complexity of it, I feel like it takes up a bigger part of the game than it should have. Sometimes it feels like I'm being spammed with gear and loot, and can't concentrate on anything else.Despite that one disadvantage, I think this game is great. I recommend it to anyone who likes this genre.

content:
Posted: May 8, 2015
												Kill monsters, complete quests, gain levels, fame, gold, and magic items.Torchlight II is a fun ARPG. You have 4 classes available, each class has 3 skill trees.Don't let the cheerful character art fool you. This game is as tactical as any other arpg (think Titan Quest) with skill management and equipment optimization needed for survival. The interface is pretty simple, click to move, click to attack. You can make it more in-depth (and efficient) by utilizing keyboard shortcuts and shift clicks.Leveling up gives attribute points and skill points. Some skills are really only useful for the first point investment. There are plenty of good builds out there. I recommend looking one up so you can build a better character.Your characters gets a pet. It's a decently useful feature. It's almost like Two-Flower's luggage from Color of Magic. It carries stuff and attacks your enemies. You don't have to walk back to town to sell off loot, you can send you pet to do that. You can also teach your pet spells.The main quest can be completed relatively quickly, but even after you finish you can replay on a harder mode. You could also try playing a different class. Also, even after completing the main quest, you do have an option to do some dungeon crawling hack and slash maps.Overall this game is pretty fun.

content:
Posted: February 18, 2013
												Mkay, so...Torchlight. If you like any of the Diablo games, then chances are you're going to like this game. It's simple enough, really...four classes to choose from, a good array of skills that you can put points into, and the ability to use any weapon in the game, regardless of your class. I think the best part about this game is you can - technically - build yourself how you want, and still have a class that works well even in increased difficulties. Only real problem is that the increased difficulty doesn't net you any rewards. It's just harder. No increased loot drops, nothin'. Heck, you actually get *less* experience points per kill, and everything is made to be more expensive, while you meanwhile get less gold per drop. There's some "meh" things about this game, but...largely? I enjoy it. Plus, mods make this game a whole lot better.

content:
Posted: July 6, 2016
												Fishing Simulator Steam Sale 2016I wanted to have my first review for something I could write fairly, not too biased, not too unknowing. Torchlight II I think fits this description.There are a few cons to Torchlight II, but they do get overthrown fairly easily with this game. So let's start with the bad.|Cons|Bugs - Yes, bugs. Not the ones you'll be killing in game or transforming your pet into either. For how long this game has been out, I was surprised to have an almost game breaking bug happen in multiplayer whenever I levelled up. My partner I was playing with would be disconnected whenever I would level. This happened for about 25 levels in game. If became a joke about having to save a million times as I was getting closer to leveling up, but it was still extremely annoying. It could've been a mod we have installed, but it has since fixed itself and said mod is still there and hasn't been updated. Pet AI - Not the greatest thing sometimes. Many times have I had a pet get stuck in a corner and not be able to move until I go back and essentially force him to move the opposite direction and then slowly walk around the corner it was getting stuck on. This doesn't happen often, but it still is a bit annoying.Fishing Time - However much I love the fishing, I hate how sometimes I can catch one in less than 3 seconds and other times I have to wait almost 20 for the circle to go grey. It adds a bit to the immersion of fish don't all bite immediately or the same, but it's still a bit of a hassle sometimes, especially to get that covetted cheevo of fishing 1000 times. Voices - I can honestly say, I don't know much about the story of the game because I can't be bothered listening to the bad voice actors of the game. Yes I can read the story, but it's more fun to just click and get back to hitting things with my sword. Truth be told though, I have a really hard time sitting there reading something when they just add massive reverb to everybody important to make them sound like a ghost or the lack of enthusiasm in most of the character's voices. Now for what we really came here for... the good stuff...|Pros|Multiplayer - Yes, it sounds crazy, a dungeon crawler Diabloesque game without multiplayer? It happened... before I bought it... hence why I have it now and not then. Great game to play multiplayer. Loot System - If you're like me and don't like playing single player with dungeon crawler games, then you'll love the loot system. No dashing in to steal everything and then break friendships for life because you Tanked and did all the damage to said boss and friend runs in and grabs your legendary class drop and wont give it to you... FML for all the times that happened. Instead, everybody has their own loot drops. Wonderful system to have and keeping friends together since 2012.Pets - Although the pet AI can stink sometimes, it's great having something to kill with. Great for tanking or ranged DPS, pets can do almost anything you can. Seriously, you can even give them spells that they can cast. It's great. There's a huge variety you can "transform" them into as well for times ranging from 5 minutes to inifite. Fishing - Again, I had my hate on for fishing earlier, but only because I have done it so much and spent hours into just sitting there in town and doing the nasty... gutting a half dead fish. 60+ bucks to sell in store or great buffs for you. Can even have your pets transform from them. Giants are a pain to get, only about 1 in 150 fishing, but still great.Mods - THANK GAWD for mods. Makes the game greater than it already is. Not as many as I would like to see, but still a great amount. It's awesome seeing a modding community that's still active with a 4 year old game (at time of posting this review... 2016).|Final Thoughts|This is the game I feel Diablo should try to take over and implement into their already decent system. It's brighter than Diablo, but I think that goes without saying. This is a great game overall and even better with friends. Do I recommend buying it for CAD $21.99? If you have a friend to play with, then yes. If you're alone, I would wait until this puppy goes on sale.|Final Score|Graphics 8.5/10Stability 6/10Sound 9/10Voices 4/10Replay Value 9.5/10Fun 9/10Overall With Voices 7.5/10True Overall 8.5/1010/10 Would fish again

content:
Posted: February 1, 2015
Does Diablo better than D3!As an avid fan of Diablo 1 and Diablo 2, I was sorely disappointed by the gameplay and support put forth by Blizzard into Diablo 3. My search for a new hack 'n' slash RPG that I could sink my teeth into began. After sinking countless hours into games like Titan Quest (which was never fully completed and released with many bugs. Still recommended though!) a couple of former Diablo developers went and made Torchlight. The first game was great: well balanced, fun, hours of replayability...but it lacked multiplayer.Torchlight 2 brings together all of the same great elements from the first release, and adds multiplayer and even more replayability with Steam Workshop's player created content! With four classes to choose from, multiple playthroughs, the ability to switch difficulty settings at any time, and high character leveling capabilities, you can literally spend weeks playing this game by yourself or with friends. My only complaint about this game is that the Embermage appears to be a bit overpowered (OP). However, if you're new to the Diablo-esque genre of hack 'n' slash, loot-♥♥♥♥♥ gaming then you may like the prospect of making things a bit easier on yourself in the early-game.Ratings out of 8 bits: 1 bit = low, 8 bits = high.Graphics: 8 bits. Although a bit dated by 2015 standards, the game's lush and colorful landscapes are almost as enticing as the myriad of color effects for spells and attacks. On many occassions I found myself snapping screenshots of exotic locales as if I were on vacation.Sound: 8 bits. Coupled with the beautiful graphics of Torchlight 2 is an amazing soundtrack of intrigue with intermittent cries of enemies as they shatter and explode.Story: 6 bits. Even though effort was put into this RPG to give it a compelling storyline, it felt forced and overused at times. The cutscenes were lower-budget than the gameplay, and, although using a different art style than Diablo, the story smacked of the Diablo storyline. Seeing the evil mage fleeing into the desert reminded me too much of the wanderer from Diablo 2 always moving East. I would have liked to have seen more of a unique storyline than just unique artwork for the cutscenes.Gameplay: 8 bits. Nothing to complain about here. Lots of unique areas to explore, dungeons to conquer, baddies to slay, and loot to horde!...with the excitement broken up by quiet fishing trips.Execution: 7 bits. Although this title brings together everythings Diablo and Torchlight fans have come to love, I can't help but feel that not enough was done to separate this title as different than Diablo 2. A few things have been changed, many improvements made, but for everything that was added it feels as if something was taken away. The ability to easily modify powerful items was added, but set items were nerfed to the point of uselessness. There are more examples, but I feel one is enough here.Overall: 8 bits. This game is a must-have for any RPG/Diabloesque gamer! Highly recommended for anyone with loads of time to spare, or someone who just wants to work their way through a fun hack 'n' slash with a great story!

content:
Posted: March 16, 2016
												Torchlight II is one of those ARPGs that comes along and does almost everything right. I don't think I can really sit here and list all the "quality of life" improvements added for the sake of streamlined gameplay that doesn't insult the consumer's intelligence. This is a solid game that's going to be relevant for a long time, especially with Salan's Synergies Mod. Seriously, that guy is doing god's work, keeping people coming back for more. Anyway, Torchlight II is your traditional ARPG that brings a lot to the table compared to first installment. All while paralelling Diablo and Diablo II. The original heroes are present in cameos with new classes taking on the mantle in a larger setting across four chapters. Each said class breaks the mold compared to Diablo II with different ability combinations that can make for some interesting builds. Some more viable than others, but you'll rarely see an "I Win" build that dominates over all. The pet is still present, allowing you to sell your junk and even pick up supplies for you to keep you focused on the action with minimal town visits. In fact, the pet is a bit more useful with its own equipment and fish you can use to transform it to other creatures, all with different stats and special attacks or simply buffs to compliment your strategy.The settings are more vast this time, taking you across different continents, all with sidequests or hidden dungeons to explore. Socketing, gems, and skulls are still present. This time with a crafting system. You can of course merge like gems together for more powerful ones. But you can also mix/match them to generate random shards/gems with different ability sets within their theme. Plus you can do the same with items and gear, creating different rare armors/weapons, or stronger potions. Most of it is trial and error based, but part of the fun is the expiremntation. Stats and skills are thankfully spelled out in a detailed tooltip. You know what to expect from what you invest in almost down to the modifier that dictates is effectiveness. No more guessing on what stats or gear is essential, but it doesn't hold your hand either as you can play around with what primary stat you want to focus on as a modifier. Vitality is a bit useless if you're not a shield user, sadly, but socketing makes up for it. Combat is fluid, satisfying, and an excellent sense of impact. Whether you're laying waste to everything in your path with spells, sniping things from a range, swinging a giant weapon, or quickly shredding everything one by one with blinding speed, there's a sense of satisfaction to what you're doing and different gauges for each class to reward you for your relentlessness. Online gameplay is going to be hit or miss at this point. The net code is solid, but with modding and vanilla sepparated, it splits the community down the middle. At least from my point of view since I did multiplayer pre-GUTS. Now, you might have trouble finding people online, depending on your time zone. Good thing there's an offline mode too. (Obligatory jab at Diablo III)I highly reccomend Torchlight II. Not only to ARPG fans, but anyone curious about the genre as it's a great place to start. Play alone, play with friends, or make new friends while playing. More than worth the full price easily. Mod it until it crashes.

												Torchlight II is basically the original game's Diablo 2, and it bares at least a dozen or so different parallels to those two games. From having an overworld, to all the classes being balanced toward each other's weaknesses, to the goal of the game being to slay the evil incarnation of the protagonist of the previous game. And my god is it awesome.Let me be blunt and say that this game's marketing strategy was amazing. The developer basically had to do next to nothing to market the game, since it was entirely carried by the fact it addresses basically every complaint people had with Diablo 3 in one fell swoop. It has no always on DRM, it has mods, local access network multiplayer and online and the list just goes on and on. It's a complete game from start to finish and like every Diablo-esque game, you're a sociopathic hero who simply just carves through entire armies worth of enemies like a hot knife through butter.This is by far one of the greatest sequels I've ever played.

content:
Posted: February 23, 2015
												Many dungeon crawlers pride themselves on lootporn. Runic Games realises it's nice to also package in an actual game with your Excel sheet, and manages to build an inviting world with a responsive and satisfying combat system.The game's story is one of tragic desperation, told across 4 acts, and while I won't spoil anything I suggest you not play this for its storyline, as it doesn't go far nor deep. Don't mistake this for a lack of charm though, as each of the game's environments are colourful and varied. From bright shining deserts to gloomy forests and snowy ... cold places. My eyes were never bored.The four classes available in the game all have their distinctive styles, but also allow for a large amount of customisation on the player's part. Many different active abilities are available to choose from, which translates to many different ways to play. Within the admittedly limited amount of classes I can almost guarantee anyone will find a build they're comfortable with. A minor point against this is that respeccing is not available in the base game. Modding rectifies this.Which brings me to my next point: The players. This game has an abundance of that whole consumer-friendliness our industry seems to relish in not caring about. You want mod support? It's in there, ranging from the smallest of tweaks to total conversions. Always online DRM? Don't be so daft, play offline if you like and have a lovely experience. What about LAN? Yeah, LAN support is in, go nuts. Also note the apparent lack of any microtransactions or locked-behind-paywalls DLC. The point I'm trying to make is that if you take the direction of the industry into account when you're considering a purchase, this is definitely not the worst option available.Lastly, I should point you to its price. This game doesn't exactly break the bank compared to most other releases of this scope. HowLongToBeat.com lists the average main story completion takes around 20 hours, that's not counting the side quests in the field, extra dungeons, mapworks (endgame dungeons) or New Game Plus mode.So what have we got? A 20ish hour flat story with a pleasing coat of paint, well flowing and varied options for combat, single- online- and LAN play and excellent mod support packed into what is a relatively inexpensive game. If your interest has been piqued I highly recommend you play this game, but if you’re on the fence I suggest having a go with the free demo first.

I've listed them down in the PROS and CONS.TL2 is slightly below Diablo in terms of content quantity... 4 levels are really, really fast to finish.... But for the price, it was worth it.... I am also very annoyed with the creation of another Runic account to link to my Steam account. I would like to be able to transfer my game to another Steam account not the one I bought it with. Another pet peeve (which can't be helped) is the feeling of repetition deeper into TL2. You can see copies of Ratlings, skeletons and Brutes appearing over and over again. They just come back with a different name and different skin.$4.00 SGDPROS1. Great map designQuests and story rolled into one. Not all the quests are in the town, some are hidden away in the map, so it makes you want to explore. However, the downside is that you might miss some of these quests as you don't know where they are. E.g. Zephari Envoy2. SecretsThere are lots of interesting secret areas. One memorable one was "It puts the lotion in the bucket" (obvious reference to Silence of the Lambs). I shouldn't spoil how to do it but let's just say it will be interesting to find the lotion.3. Skill treesI like the way you can upgrade your skills and that there are so many skills to work with, per character. Each skill is tiered into T1, T2, T3 with a special upgrade at each tier. There are a lot of way to play your character.4. Semi-Live NPCsThe NPCs give you information on current events which are related to your quests and they don't function purely as lamp posts. I think they could have made it better by making the NPCs come alive even more though.5. Train TravelAlthough a cut-scene, it was cool. I was hoping to interact with the train though. I think that it would be better if we could go onto the train and do stuff on it.6. InteractionQuite a few items but not everything. You can break urns, rocks, explosives and barrels but those are a given. Lighting the braziers to provide light was most innovative. I think having levers or switchs that moved big bridges would be quite cool.7. Knocking creatures offThere are some ways to knock off tiny land creatures, off the terrain and into a pit. Very cool, much better than an invisible ring. Of course, you can be knocked off as well.8. Pack mule / PetI love my pet and the ability to sell items without going back to town. 9. Spider MinesI can't believe there are spider mines that seek out enemies.10. Alternate weaponsPress W. Switch from range to melee. Great move. Change playstyle instantly. *Star star*11. NPC huntingYou can get more NPCs to help out in the town if you go out of your way to do side quests. Again, a potential pitfall as you might miss them totally, but it's okay. The similarity to Suikoden's hero collection is great.CONS1. BugsCan't pick up items that fall onto ledgesCan't shoot creatures who are no more than a few feet above or below you.2. Murder HoboAlmost everything is still mass murder. Kill, kill, kill, kill and more killing for any quest. I'm a mass murderer in this game. I've yet to come across a quest without premeditated murder.3. Stupid thingsYou are face-to-face with an enemy. However, you can't reach him because of a crack that runs through the floor, dividing you and the enemy. Most ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥. I think a jump would be great.4. Runic Account creationMost annoying. I have to create another account just to play online. <------ This here pisses me off.5. Spell keys1,2,3,4 are easy to reach. 5,6,7,8,9,0 extremely hard. Would have been better with 1234QWER.6. RepetitionRatlings, goo, skeletons repeated. Just with a different colour palette and skin.7. FameWhat does this do?8. ContentOnly 4 levels. I breezed through them. It didn't feel like there was enough interesting stuff. Just lots of similar level bashing.NEUTRAL1. Trash dropsI am not so certain about trash drops that just keep on generating a lot of junk for me to sell. Perhaps, something else can be done about trash drops?SUGGESTIONSI saw ladders in the game. Could Runic code an interaction with ladders?

												A quick preface:I extremely dislike Perfect World Entertainment. After having worked with them many years as a consumer attempting to enjoy some of their products, I find it difficult to recommend anything that they oversee. This is a word of caution, stranger.With the negativity out of the way...! Torchlight II is a sublime game. Colorful and vivid visuals mesh with professional sound quality and gameplay design features. I have put plenty of time and effort into the game and can easily recommend it to gamers looking for a 'classical' experience.Torchlight II is an action role-playing game not unlike the Diablo franchise. Immerse yourself in a fantasy world rife with conflict and unique people, places, and ideas. Play one of four classes and then embark on a journey to customize your character even further with three skill trees for each of the archetypes. Bring friends along, tackle procedurally generated dungeons, and advance in the engaging storyline as a casual gamer or passionate 'min-maxer'.Torchlight II is an exceptional game that can keep you occupied for hours, if not days.... perhaps weeks!

												Well, this review is not for those who like this kind of RPGs. Rather, I would pen it down for those few like me who usually hate top down. Well, I love action RPGs - fallout 3, Fallout New Vegas and Skyrim are the among the best single player experiences I can remember. But when it comes to top down, I just used to have a scorn for the genre.I tried diablo 3, torchlight and torchlight 2 (a torchlight fan) at a friend's house long back. I hated it and never looked towards it for months to come. It is accidentally that I had some $4.00 in my wallet and TL2 was on sale that I purchased it. I wanted to try it again, even though I was 99% sure it won't appeal me.I was wrong. The game is GREAT. But to realize its greatness, there are three things you must keep in mind:- Don't think that you are playing an action game. There is very little skill of swiftness on mouse and keyboard required in this game. So, definitely not an action game.- Play it for at least 15 hours, level up to level 25 and then judge.... things keep on adding, new skills start appearing, interesting scrolls begin dropping out of chests and skilled monsters... it is then that you understand how amazing this game is.- If you are dying more, it is not that you are not able to deliver enough clicks-per-second, it just means that each of the clicks has an ignorantly cascaded set of skills behind it. So, activate the right skills and wear the right armor. I started learning new things about the mechanics when I was 3 hours into the game and am learning totally new things till now (e.g. For torchlight 2 players - sets of armor... the purple thing written in some armor's description... something I learnt at mty 29th hour).I played the game for 15 hours on normal, realized that I was very ignorant about the game's mechanics, deleted my character, started a veteran character and adorned it with better perks this time... continuing with it.... glad that I started the game again..HAPPY GAMING!

												A great RPG that I could recommend to anyone.Torchlight II is an absolutely gigantic game with tons of possibilities. There are 4 different classes which all have their strenghts and weaknesses. Each class has 3 different skill trees which contain both passive and active skills. Most skills require you to be a pretty high level though, so getting your desired skills and have them at a high rank will definitely take you some time.The levels in Torchlight are huge! They are filled with lots of enemies, NPCs and objects that will have you fighting and exploring for a while. After you've completed the game, you have the chance to play a few bonus maps with various buffs and de-buffs or you can decide to play the game over again with the same character, but with the enemies adjusted to your current character level.There's also a big variety of weapons in the game. Melee weapons like staves, spears, axes, swords and ranged weapons like crossbows, guns and wands. Some classes have skills in their skill tree that allows you to increase your proficiency with a certain weapon type. Torchlight II has an added workshop which allows you to make use of the many mods that are made for this game. Mods can add different characters, game mechanics or even more weapons like throwing axes, throwing knives and claws.All of that said, I can definitely recommend Torchlight II to anyone that is into Hack and Slash RPGs. Prepare for hours of fun and tons of achievements to unlock!

content:
Posted: March 13, 2015
												It is inevitable to compare this game to Blizzard's hack 'n slash RPG. I would say this would be the poor-man's version of Diablo III, but the truth of the matter is Torchlight II holds it's ground and could even be considered a better game overall, depending on what you're looking for.Torchlight II brings better loot, better progressions system, mob variety and arguably a better 'end-game'. The only two thing it lacks, compared to Diablo III, is the graphical fidelity (although since the game is done in a cartoonish art-style, it is not immediately noticable) and story.While Torchlight II manages to win points in the atmosphere department, the story of the Diablo universe offers a much more expanded lore and world to explore. Voice acting, cinematics and sound design are far better than what Torchlight II has. Which is to be expected from a series that started it's roots in indie gaming. Experience sharing in multiplayer could use some tweaking, but loot is instanced for every player and trading is fully functional for all items you find. A big plus for the game is also mod support, something which Diablo III lacks. The Steam Workshop is sure to increase the life-span of the game, and enchance the experience according to your taste buds.Despite some of it's shortcomings, it is still one of the better hack 'n slash RPGs out there. Definitely worth your time!

Posted: June 2, 2015
												Torchlight II is a really good game, but not a great game. It has an endearing art-style that's easy on the eyes, and the gameplay is addictive enough to keep you playing 'till the end (I played about 50 hours by the time I beat it). However, there is nothing about this game that is exceptional or raises the bar. The story isn't deep or engaging, and the world lacks depth. Had the developers expanded the towns and added sub characters to strengthen the plot, then this game could have been a bench mark. The loot drops are well-balanced and look decent, the world is visually appealing, even interesting in some places, and the monsters are well-designed. But beyond the relentless grind, there's nothing much motivating you to keep collecting and throwing away loot 'till the next boss fight, except more loot and boss fights, that is. If you're just looking for a game to help you pass the time without being bored, then it does its job well, but don't expect an engaging story to justify the 50+ hours you may waste playing it. In the end, I feel like I got my money's worth, but only based on what I already kind of expected.

content:
Posted: February 23, 2015
												Many dungeon crawlers pride themselves on lootporn. Runic Games realises it's nice to also package in an actual game with your Excel sheet, and manages to build an inviting world with a responsive and satisfying combat system.The game's story is one of tragic desperation, told across 4 acts, and while I won't spoil anything I suggest you not play this for its storyline, as it doesn't go far nor deep. Don't mistake this for a lack of charm though, as each of the game's environments are colourful and varied. From bright shining deserts to gloomy forests and snowy ... cold places. My eyes were never bored.The four classes available in the game all have their distinctive styles, but also allow for a large amount of customisation on the player's part. Many different active abilities are available to choose from, which translates to many different ways to play. Within the admittedly limited amount of classes I can almost guarantee anyone will find a build they're comfortable with. A minor point against this is that respeccing is not available in the base game. Modding rectifies this.Which brings me to my next point: The players. This game has an abundance of that whole consumer-friendliness our industry seems to relish in not caring about. You want mod support? It's in there, ranging from the smallest of tweaks to total conversions. Always online DRM? Don't be so daft, play offline if you like and have a lovely experience. What about LAN? Yeah, LAN support is in, go nuts. Also note the apparent lack of any microtransactions or locked-behind-paywalls DLC. The point I'm trying to make is that if you take the direction of the industry into account when you're considering a purchase, this is definitely not the worst option available.Lastly, I should point you to its price. This game doesn't exactly break the bank compared to most other releases of this scope. HowLongToBeat.com lists the average main story completion takes around 20 hours, that's not counting the side quests in the field, extra dungeons, mapworks (endgame dungeons) or New Game Plus mode.So what have we got? A 20ish hour flat story with a pleasing coat of paint, well flowing and varied options for combat, single- online- and LAN play and excellent mod support packed into what is a relatively inexpensive game. If your interest has been piqued I highly recommend you play this game, but if you’re on the fence I suggest having a go with the free demo first.

However, the downside is that you might miss some of these quests as you don't know where they are. E.g. Zephari Envoy2. SecretsThere are lots of interesting secret areas. One memorable one was "It puts the lotion in the bucket" (obvious reference to Silence of the Lambs). I shouldn't spoil how to do it but let's just say it will be interesting to find the lotion.3. Skill treesI like the way you can upgrade your skills and that there are so many skills to work with, per character. Each skill is tiered into T1, T2, T3 with a special upgrade at each tier. There are a lot of way to play your character.4. Semi-Live NPCsThe NPCs give you information on current events which are related to your quests and they don't function purely as lamp posts. I think they could have made it better by making the NPCs come alive even more though.5. Train TravelAlthough a cut-scene, it was cool. I was hoping to interact with the train though. I think that it would be better if we could go onto the train and do stuff on it.6. InteractionQuite a few items but not everything. You can break urns, rocks, explosives and barrels but those are a given. Lighting the braziers to provide light was most innovative. I think having levers or switchs that moved big bridges would be quite cool.7. Knocking creatures offThere are some ways to knock off tiny land creatures, off the terrain and into a pit. Very cool, much better than an invisible ring. Of course, you can be knocked off as well.8. Pack mule / PetI love my pet and the ability to sell items without going back to town. 9. Spider MinesI can't believe there are spider mines that seek out enemies.10. Alternate weaponsPress W. Switch from range to melee. Great move. Change playstyle instantly. *Star star*11. NPC huntingYou can get more NPCs to help out in the town if you go out of your way to do side quests. Again, a potential pitfall as you might miss them totally, but it's okay. The similarity to Suikoden's hero collection is great.CONS1. BugsCan't pick up items that fall onto ledgesCan't shoot creatures who are no more than a few feet above or below you.2. Murder HoboAlmost everything is still mass murder. Kill, kill, kill, kill and more killing for any quest. I'm a mass murderer in this game. I've yet to come across a quest without premeditated murder.3. Stupid thingsYou are face-to-face with an enemy. However, you can't reach him because of a crack that runs through the floor, dividing you and the enemy. Most ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥. I think a jump would be great.4. Runic Account creationMost annoying. I have to create another account just to play online. <------ This here pisses me off.5. Spell keys1,2,3,4 are easy to reach. 5,6,7,8,9,0 extremely hard. Would have been better with 1234QWER.6. RepetitionRatlings, goo, skeletons repeated. Just with a different colour palette and skin.7. FameWhat does this do?8. ContentOnly 4 levels. I breezed through them. It didn't feel like there was enough interesting stuff. Just lots of similar level bashing.NEUTRAL1. Trash dropsI am not so certain about trash drops that just keep on generating a lot of junk for me to sell. Perhaps, something else can be done about trash drops?SUGGESTIONSI saw ladders in the game. Could Runic code an interaction with ladders?

												A quick preface:I extremely dislike Perfect World Entertainment. After having worked with them many years as a consumer attempting to enjoy some of their products, I find it difficult to recommend anything that they oversee. This is a word of caution, stranger.With the negativity out of the way...! Torchlight II is a sublime game. Colorful and vivid visuals mesh with professional sound quality and gameplay design features. I have put plenty of time and effort into the game and can easily recommend it to gamers looking for a 'classical' experience.Torchlight II is an action role-playing game not unlike the Diablo franchise. Immerse yourself in a fantasy world rife with conflict and unique people, places, and ideas. Play one of four classes and then embark on a journey to customize your character even further with three skill trees for each of the archetypes. Bring friends along, tackle procedurally generated dungeons, and advance in the engaging storyline as a casual gamer or passionate 'min-maxer'.Torchlight II is an exceptional game that can keep you occupied for hours, if not days.... perhaps weeks!

Posted: December 7, 2013
												Torchlight II reminds me of a couple of other typical "looter" games such as "Diablo" or the latest F2P game "Path of Exile". However, a few features ultimately standout from these other games which is why I highly recommend this game over the others. First, you do not have to be a diehard gamer in order to play this game. There are 4 difficulty tiers, and even the second tier (normal) feels relatively easy to an experienced player, even if you have never played another looter-type game. Second, since it is mainly a point-and-click-RPG game, one may believe they would get tired of the game after but a few moments. This is hardly the case as all the little features and nuances work beautifully together to bring you an experience that is immediately rewarding and highly addictive unlike other alternatives. Lastly, while it is a relatively fast-paced game, it seems to be more manageable in the gameplay department across the board for any player in comparison to what I have seen from Path of Exile. This just further demonstrates that just because it is free, does not mean that is better for you in the long run. Oh, and the best part is...I've only been talking about the single player experience. This game also possesses a co-op feature so you can play through the story with several friends, or even random strangers. Player trading is also included, so expect hours to pass by if you play this game with people you enjoy being around and love killing creatures with them. Now Torchlight II does have a few odd in-game features to it I've noticed. For one, the blood animations do not seem even remotely realistic (even by fantasy standards). You could kill an enemy and they would first explode followed by the entire wall being entirely covered in blood...which the wall could be 10 times your size and your enemy's size, so this makes absolutely no sense. Also, the enemies sometimes get stuck in the most random places, which allows you to easily snipe them and pick away at their health continuously if you like utilizing a ranged character and those style tactics. I've already done this with a few mini-bosses and laughed all the while. Lastly, I honestly wish I did not have to click for every attack. I wish there was some auto-attack feature after you have targeted an enemy, but this is just me being nit-picky at this point. If you notice, these are just minor issues as well. I have seen no major problems or adversities to mention from this game so far as you can plainly see as well.Ultimately, Torchlight II provides a unique, personalized, open world experience which gives games such as the Diablo series a run for its money, especially when it is on sale in the steam store. I highly recommend picking this game up when it is on sale, as you will not be disappointed with the many hours you will invest into this game alone or with friends. Now, excuse me as I go bandage up my index finger for the next extensive click-fest that I am about to perform in this game.

content:
Posted: September 27, 2016
Product received for free
What Is Torchlight II?Torchlight II is one of those wildly popular Steam games which hardly requires any introduction for fans of isometric-style action RPG's. Developed by Runic Games in 2012 as a more polished and refined version of its previous incarnation (Torchlight), it is widely hailed and beloved by scores of fanatical gamers (well over 3 million+) for its many favorable similarities to the equally popular Diablo series.The true hallmark of this title however, is that the sprawling world it offers to you on a very reasonably priced silver platter is a gorgeously inviting one awaiting to be explored to its fullest....tempting you with countless secrets to uncover & treasures to collect. In fact there is more loot to be found hidden within its myriad of locations than you could possibly wrap your mind around. It's easily one of those gems with which you can sink hundreds of hours into, since it offers level randomization for enhanced replayability inside of its open world system...one which includes weather as well as day/night cycles incidentally.GameplayFeaturing a very tight local + online co-op mode (in addition to solo offline play), you'll soon notice that you will be introduced to a diverse bounty of seemingly never-ending quests & side-quests given to you by those who require your assistance in one way or another. And fortunately, you'll have a ferocious pet by your side to help out in battle as needed, one who even possesses its own inventory!  In addition to the exploration and loot collecting, your primary objective will be to battle against a wide assortment of variously menacing monsters as you gradually level up your character with more skills, gold, and gear during this compelling campaign. Action is very fluid, brisk, and energetic...with a satisfying number of both weapon upgrades and weapon types (including melee & guns) to keep you more than entertained.Both your mana (ie. energy) and health bars will be depleted during combat, and must be replenished as necessary with collected vials which can be used up at any time.Character customization is present, although somewhat limited and basic in scope I felt. It's probably the most glaring aspect of the game which could have been improved further still. Nonetheless, it is still present at least, and you'll have your choice of either male/female characters spread across 4 distinct classes: Embermage, Outlander, Berserker, Engineer.Level design was quite impressive & varied in an overall sense, with some specific areas like the dungeons being especially atmospheric. It was quite a joy for me to explore every single nook & cranny of each individual section traversed as I hunted around for items to collect between waves of enemies....who themselves were sufficiently unique enough throughout the campaign so as to not feel repetitious in any way.There is just so very much to do in the game, and even after investing a few quality hours into it, there was an undeniable feeling that I've still only barely scratched the surface as to what awaits me further into its story.GraphicsWhat I especially appreciated about the presentation, is that this world is surprisingly vibrant in color as opposed to being dreary & muted looking in appearance as some other such similar games are. Which is then reinforced furthermore by the distinctly cartoon-style graphics found here. This in turn is all neatly tied together by a very well-done lighting system which somehow breathes a sense of intriguing realism into this magical place. All in all, it is quite pleasant on the eyes and sports a unique charm to it. And best of all, there are an ample number of graphics options available for fine-tuning your display preferences.AudioVoice acting was definitely above par, and sounded quite slick for the many varied characters present. (Although at times I felt that your character's obsession with his depleted mana levels was a bit overly-repetitive!). Whereas music itself was mellow & symphonic in nature...wonderfully balancing out the mood of each particular scene in an appropriate manner. And finally, sound effects were more than adequate in accomplishing their task of enhancing immersion...especially so with delightful effects such as thunder reverberating through the rainy night, for example. Steamified?It fully is, and includes both trading cards and a whopping 119 achievements to be unlocked.DLCNone available.ModsThe vast collection of available mods via the Steam Workshop is where this game truly shines like no other. There are literally hundreds of them to choose from in every possible category imaginable, and quite honestly you could find pretty much anything your little heart desires here.Verdict - 9/10Torchlight II has to be one of the best values out there in ARPG's...because while it only costs a fraction of what its pricier triple-A competitors do, it nonetheless very much competes as one, and more importantly, feels like one with its overhauled & redesigned user-interface which was a breeze to use. Accessibility is fantastic here as well, showcasing a streamlined and mostly straight-forward character leveling system which I greatly appreciated. Because being hopelessly confused inside of skill trees is not my personal idea of a fun time, and here, they most certainly get it right in steering the focus onto actual gameplay instead. And along with its multiple difficulty settings, just about anyone can enjoy what it has to offer...from the very casual side of the spectrum for those who simply wish to explore its scenery, all the way up to the no-nonsense hardcore setting for those veterans out there who wish to master its more subtle nuances. All in all, Torchlight II has underwent quite a lot of refinement to date, and runs at fantastic framerates even on less than cutting-edge hardware. But most of all, this is an exciting world to step inside of and one which you can very much have a great time with since there is always something interesting to do along with an accompanying sense of accomplishment felt as each goal is successfully completed...and that is why...I'll gladly rate this one a 9/10Pros:- Many hours of fun with lots to do and much to explore- Impressively designed & vast isometric world with vibrantly colorful aesthetics- Wonderfully implemented dynamic zoom camera- Nice selection of weapons + gear- Can play as both male or female- Great value for the purchase price- Rebindable keys- Impressive amount of adjustable graphics options- Local/online co-op + offline single-player - Steam achievements + trading cards- Countless mods available via the Steam WorkshopCons:- Character customization system could be more robust- Some of the character speech is repeated a bit too often For similar reviews and great giveaways please visit http://www.steamified.com

Posted: July 22, 2016
												*This review will be downvoted to hell by fans*Summary:Torchlight II clings to its Diablo series heritage like no other. It tries to be, at the same time, both fresh and familiar to fans of the genre. In the end, It’s just a cartoony Diablo II clone with elaborated gameplay mechanics. Both gives a mixture that seems appetizing but in reality is just stale and plain boring.6/10The Good :- Many, many weapons and items- Pets- Overally polished- Good musicThe Bad :- Very repetitive gameplay, even for hack'n'slash- Bland atmosphere and plot- Feels like cartoony clone of Diablo II- Dated graphicsI did not finish the game. My review follows these situations rarely. Even more rarely, I’m struggling to like something. This time, it’s Torchlight II.As serious as I can be, this fight ensued the moment I started the game and ceased when it ended up in a virtual dump. Don’t get me wrong, I adore hack’n’slash RPG’s.I absolutely loved Diablo I and more so, Diablo II. First part created the genre with gloomy atmosphere and revolutionary gameplay. The sequel had the magic to keep you clicking so many times, one would believe you’re testing mouse manufacturer’s claims of billion click durability. Torchlight II has neither. And here’s why.Right of the bat, Torchlight II shows resemblance to Diablo II. Made by the same author, the music is unmistakable. At first, I was glad because I really enjoy these notes but at the same time it prevents Torchlight to be unique. Several sounds, like opening a teleport, are basically cloned from Diablo II. Even the sequence of worlds and it’s hubs in TL are the same as Diablo II – wilderness, desert, dense forest, hell. And just like in Diablo II, our nemesis is a mysterious traveler that we’re always one step behind from. All of this takes away from Torchlight II. It’s just too familiar to call it a world of its own. It’s a copy with cartoony overlay which makes it neither dark and gloomy, nor light-hearted.As years passed, hack’n’slash games had to mutate it’s formula to remain fresh and attractive to gamers. Happily, Torchlight II has some tweaks and non-standard ideas, one of which is company of your pet. Essentialy, it’s your coop friend. There are several pets to choose from, all of which can pick and store items for you, wear accessories, fight, cast spells and last but totally not list, do a little shoppin while you bash evil’s head. You can also fish for, well, fishes that for reasons unknown, can transform your pet into a killing beast.As It goes for Diablo clones, you have a lot to choose from to do that. Beside leveling, getting a good equipment is the core element of action RPG’s. Torchlight II gives you –collecting sets, enchanting, socketing and putting in gems. Unfortunately, beside collecting and buying spells that can be used by any class, I can’t find anything that discerns Torchlight from other ARPG’s. Speaking of classes, I didn’t play every class. I focused mainly on Engineer. What I found out, is that I played through majority of the game using only 4 out of dozens. I’ve tried more variety but I’ve always ended up coming back to previous skills as they work best. So it all came down to getting the right equipment. Though you’ll encounter or buy many, many stuff it’s not that easy to find an upgrade. I’ve completed 3/4 of the game using just 3 ranged weapons with a single tactic. Single tactic, because even though monsters seem to vary much, the’re all killed the same. On hard difficulty I didn’t though that Tourchlight II is challenging, not even for a wihle)That said, it was hard to not get bored. Accompanied by generic maps, plot that isn’t worth mentioning (which I won’t) and repetitiveness with no challenge, I was struck with remorse while playing Torchlight II. Remorse that told me, that time with Torchlight II could be spent way better or at least on a superior game. Torchlight II is an OK ARPG, that excels in mediocrity. If ARPG’s are your thing, you could bite the bullet, especially that it’s dirt cheap now, but don’t say that I didn’t warn you.

Posted: December 1, 2013
												I honestly couldn’t believe it at first, but Torchlight II is indeed a massive improvement over the original. I can’t tell you how it compares to Diablo or other Diablo clones, but I can tell you it’s an action RPG that trounces its predecessor in terms of variety and breadth of content.At its base TII has you doing the same things as in the original Torchlight, but Runic Games seems to have done everything it could to make grinding for look more exciting with more places to go, more interesting classes, and more abilities to unlock.Instead of just running around in one town, one main dungeon, and a bunch of extra random dungeons, TII gives you an actual world to explore, split into several environments, each with a main and side dungeons as well as its own visual identity. The first thing I noticed about TII in videos was probably that it had a distinctly different and livelier color palette than the first game. TII looks fresher and a lot more aesthetically pleasing than the first game pretty much just due to better art direction. The first two areas in particular -- a steppe inhabited by monks, and a snowy mountainside, really helped draw me into the game.All TII’s new classes seem to be interesting departures from the norm. In the original Torchlight I ended up picking the class that felt most familiar to me which was the warrior/tank dude. The closest thing in TII is the Berserker which I ended up enjoying a lot more. Yeah Berserkers still just tank everywhere, but the added focus on critical hits, their berserker meter and weapons like claws instead of swords and shields makes playing the class more interesting in my opinion.TII’s sound design also creates a great sense of tactile feedback. Not only does the impact of landing hits in combat sound satisfying, but even the menu interface feels and sounds better when you’re assigning upgrade points and unlocking abilities. I think it helps drive home a sense of real craftsmanship that reminds you TII was indeed made by professional game developers.The best thing Runic did to help get people into TII was creating its excellent demo, which by itself I found to be pretty addicting. It’s basically the first area -- the steppe, stopping after the completion of the first main quest. And even afterwards you can still just mess around in that area which is what I did for a while before buying the game. Once you do you can carry your progress over.TII also adds a New Game+ in which you loop your old character back through the game with enemies leveled higher. You can do this and have enemies level ever higher five times (for a total of six runs through the game). You can keep looping infinitely after that but enemies won’t get any stronger. TII also has multiplayer but I’ve actually only done solo so far.Lastly, TII has been reported to be able to run on integrated graphics, though I can’t confirm this 100 percent.$20 might be a lot for an indie game, but after learning how much content and variety was packed into TII, $20 feels like an excellent price for it.

Posted: August 19, 2015
												FULL REVIEW:Gameplay: 10/10Torchlight II, by Runic Games, expands the Torchlight universe from where it first started in the original game. Torchlight II is an improvement in pretty much every way. For people who say that this game is a Diablo copy, it's not. Diablo doesn't have companions that fight for you, sell your stuff, and look adorable. There are four classes, and you can pretty much build them however you want. Levelling up your skills is easy and you can master some sick combos. There's really no wrong way to play Torchlight, which is what sets it apart from most ARPGs where you're expected to stick to some meta that the devs make for you.Monsters are challenging, bosses and side quests are VERY rewarding, and you can really feel like a (good) marauder in the deserts or swamps of Torchlight.Story: 4/10Well, it's an ARPG...don't expect much if you're looking for story. The story is very generic and there's no real characters that you side with or feel bad for. It's the classic chaotic-evil robot dude trying to wreck humanity with lots of baddies along the way.Other: 9/10Torchlight II can be modded, and Runic Games even made a mod creator so that you can mod the game for yourself! Additionally, you can play in local co-op, which in my opinion is where the replayability comes from. The few flaws in this game are just some minor crashes and that you end up having too many abilities for your own good. Someone should make a mod where you get another action bar. Seriously.Final verdict: 8.5/10Torchlight II is probably the best ARPG dungeon crawler on Steam. The art style is wonderful, the gameplay is exhilarating, and you'll always find yourself crawling back to try out new classes that people made online or going on hardcore mode with friends. The flaws are minimal, and overall it's a close to perfect game with plenty of fun to offer.

Posted: December 10, 2015
												Coming from somebody that did play Diablo 2 back in the day (and wasn't as fond of it as other people), this game takes the typical frustrating aspects of that game and throws them out the window. While it's possible that Diablo 3 does some of these things as well, I'm afraid I haven't played that game yet. First, you can load up your pet with unwanted loot and send it back to town while in the middle of a dungeon to sell for you. Generally returning after two minutes. You can even have it purchase stuff in town for you, like potions or scrolls. It's so nice to not have to constantly port back to town to empty out my inventory. You also don't have to click on gold to pick it up. You just have to walk over it. I may never play Diablo 2 again after getting used to such a nice feature. You get a hotbar for skills. You don't even need to have potions take up space on it because pressing Z or X automatically uses your best healing or mana potion. So I can press 1 for a firestorm, press 2 for fire pillars, press 3 to summon a ghost, etc. It kinda feels like playing an MMO. You can find ambiguous spells on any character that you can have four of equiped at any time, offering some variety into your gameplay. Like a spell that summons a horde of zombies, or a simple fireball, or a passive buff to your EXP and gold earned. The really cool part is that your pet also gets four spell slots and will use any spells automatically when you get into a fight and they're off cooldown. I have my pet set to summon two hordes of zombies AND some skeleton archers, with a passive spell that increases his damage and shortens the time it takes for him to get back from town. There's so much this game does right that it makes me kinda disappointed that the devs have moved on to other projects and don't plan to update Torchlight 2 anymore. But still, the game has easy intigration built in for the modding community. Totally recommended.

Posted: October 8, 2014
												Experience of playing as 2-handed engy on Veteran Act III: "wtf just hit me I'm dead"This game is good. From the soothing string music to humorous weapon descriptions, there is a lot to see and play.  Loot drops rate are just right. Game mechanics are tight and well done (aside from the armor system) You don't have to go crazy on grinding for a proper weapon. Unique-tier weapons look pretty cool and have great descriptions to boot. Their damage and stats also fit your requirements for reasonably long, unlike that one FPS where your purple-rarity gun does♥♥♥♥♥♥damage 2-3 levels later. Apples to oranges. I don't care.The inclusion of "Arcane Stats", where you can see your actual damage output, proc chances, actual armor after bonuses factor in, etc, is really, really useful. This helps a lot in planning your build, and you don't have to do convoluted calculations to find your optimum loadout, and try to figure out whether a particular bonus is additive, multiplicative, applied post-multiplication, blahblah.The UI is very well built, comparing gear is easy, organizing items is easy, weapon damage is listed in DPS (honestly, why the hell not).However, when it comes to the really-high difficulties (NG+ Veteran, NG Elite, Mapworks), the armor system starts to show some bad problems if you play a tanking class. Armor damage reduction is calculated point-by-point rather as a percentage. Meaning if you have 800 armor, you will reduce an incoming attack by 800 damage. To play a serious build during Elite NG++ levels, you will have to farm for damage reduction socketables if you plan on consistently not dying when a mob so much as breathes on you.To quote Cthon from the TL2 forums:"Armor is basically meaningless. Not only is it badly outscaled by monster damage, but its effectiveness is also reduced by any damage reduction you have. To be as charitable as possible to armor, it's reasonably effective early on before monster damage scaling really gets going. A player who only did the first playthrough and did not do mapworks or NG+ might not encounter very many situations where no feasible amount of armor makes a meaningful difference."^This applies to anything above normal difficulty.Again, nobody cares about the story. Play on veteran mode if you've played RPGs before, normal is kinda easy.
