Posted: December 3, 2012
												best diablo cloneEdit: Since recommendations have apparently been converted into reviews I thought I should elaborate a bit.First off: TL2 is not as good as Diablo 2. After playing it for a bit again, 70 hours or so, I tried D2 again and the better gameplay and design choices just felt really immediate. I went on to go for Patriarch again. That said TL2 is the best of the "clones" I've played. It's not worthy as a successor but as with some other genres it seems that the pioneer will always remain the greatest.Regarding graphics. At their best, the graphics look fantastic. TL2 in 60 FPS is really something that must be seen to be believed. Unfortunately the graphics are unusually heavy, and most computers will find it hard to keep the framerate high, especially in big battles. Said big kerfuffles also bring to light another problem regarding the visuals. They're very busy. So busy in fact, that in the multiplayer each player has a column of blue light emanating from them so that you can identify players in the mess. This is not a good thing, relatively I say that D2 still has better graphics, not because they're flashy with advanced effects, but because they're concise and serve the gameplay. Freeze, poison, curses and auras, other important spells etc. are easy to identify in D2, in TL2 not so much. The overabundance of various effects and the subtlety of others makes the graphics not serve gameplay so well.Thematically, TL2 is obviously a big deviator when it comes to comparing to D2. If you can get over it, the visual design is occasionally pretty stunning. However at times it feels somewhat generic, as "cartoony á la WoW" has become the go-to fantasy style over the past ten years or so.  The gameplay is a mixed bag. The skill system is simpler than D2's all across the board, but the attributes are done differently. One of the usual complaints in D2 is that other than the mandatory Strength and Dexterity points, all points for all characters go in Vitality. In TL2 all attributes are useful for every character in some fashion, but optimal distribution is usually just stacking Strength or Focus, as those are the attributes that increase damage by a percentage. Vitality is not as useful as in D2, as the HP increase is not as important and because the other bonus granted from it is block and armor increase, which tends to be useful for shielded characters only. Dexterity gives minor things like critical change, dodge and fumble recovery. Fumble is another mechanic new to TL2, instead of missing, characters can Fumble their autoattacks which makes them cause reduced damage. The reason for this seems to be making the combat feel more satisfying, as characters missing with attacks is a common complaint with action RPGs. However it usually seems to just make it more frustrating, at least for me, as Fumble just makes it look like your character just barely scratches the enemies with his autoattacks, with no clear reason, as fumbled attacks look the same as normal ones. The constant fumbling combined with relatively powerful active skills makes builds involving large amounts of auto-attack rare and/or not that useful. In comparison to D2, most every melee attack utilized auto-attack attack speeds, life leech, etc. but in TL2 very few of those kinds of bonuses apply to the active skills. And because the actives do much more damage and other things, relying on auto-attack and utilizing the bonuses for it is seldom a sensible option. Regarding skills, as mentioned, the system is not as robust as Diablo 2's. Skills are divided into three "trees", but you don't need to invest in prerequisites, so they're more like categories instead of trees. There are no synergies, so builds come down to using skills that work well with each other, or just spamming the most overpowered skill possible, like the Engineer's Emberquake. The skill scaling is different: instead of diminishing returns like D2, TL2 goes with flat increases every rank, as in rank 1: 9% dodge, rank 2: 12% dodge, rank 3: 15% dodge, etc. This is a double-edged sword. On one hand skill increases stay meaningful all the way to the end. Some skills in D2 hit diminishing returns hard which meant that there wasn't really a point in spending more than a few points in certain skills. On the other hand, especially at the start, the skill increases feel petty and unimportant. For instance: would you rather spend another point in the skill to gain 2% more damage, or buy a new skill altogether that does good damage with just one point in it, and even scales (a new feature in TL2)?Scaling is another point. Most skills scale in damage with level, generally with skills that do flat amounts of damage instead of weapon damage. Weapon damage is another problem in itself. A disproportionally large amount of skills rely on weapon damage, even the Embermage's and Outlander's more spell-like abilities. In addition to it not making much sense, it also makes your weapon, and its DPS to be more precise, overly important. Some builds in D2 relied more on weapons, and usually it was regarded as a weakness. In TL2 most builds need weapon damage which makes the DPS the focal point of gear. The other bonuses aren't that important, especially considering that several weapon enchantments only activate on autoattacks, like mentioned. Gear as a whole is not nearly as well thought out as in D2. Because it's the only real source for HP, most every item choice on Veteran and beyond is decided by the amount of health on the item. In D2, most characters got plenty of health from Vitality, and life on gear was relatively rare, so it wasn't that important. In TL2 you MUST stack health to stand a chance on the harder difficulties. This combined with the underwhelming bonuses of the other usual enchantments meas that itemization is  banal and pointless. Adding to this problem is the fact that most uniques have boring, nonsensical or otherwise worthless bonuses that make them unique only in the sense that you'd have to be a real hipster to ever equip them, most of the time. Their drop rate is overly high too, and some bosses even drop guaranteed uniques, most notably the last boss which always drops two. Sets are done a little differently. Set is more like an enchantment instead of an item rarity, and two of the same set item can be worn and it will still count towards completion. This makes them much more common and more viable for non-twinks, but causes them to lose their uniqueness quite a bit. The aforementioed health stacking is also a limiting factor regarding sets, as some just don't want to spawn with HP on them.The inclusion of multiplayer was something that was highly anticipated. Unfortunately it works in about the same manner as Open Battle.net in D2, which makes it pretty worthless for anything serious. There are rudimentary anti-cheating features in place but with local saves anything resembling ladders or an economy is just a futile effort. Another pretty big blunder is the unbelievable amount of player separation. D2 had realms, ladder and non-ladder and hardcore and softcore. TL2 has Casual, Normal, Veteran, Elite, NG, NG+, NG++, etc., hardcore and softcore, so maybe you see my point. The player base gets splintered into so many sections that it really hurts the ability to play with others. So mainly the multiplayer is only good for playing with friends. Also, the loot is instanced, depending on point of view this is a good or a bad thing.It might seem like I'm complaining about everything but I feel like I'm just scratching the surface, but my point is that it's not as good as Diablo 2, but an OK clone on its own, and fun for its own reasons. Recommended if you want to play solo or with a friend for a bit for fun, but not if you're looking for the next greatest aRPG/dungeon crawler/hack'n'slash/click looter/diablo clone/whatever. For that we have D2 still.

												Enough of the Diablo 2 comparisons - the genre has evolved enough to......wait....ha ha who the hell am I kidding. Torchlight 2 is something like Antje Traue; it's silently risen to the apex of its genre (or in Traue's case, she's climbed over the plastic American bimbos from Hollywood and has become the most attractive woman in the universe). I was never too interested in the first TL game, but this was mostly because I was ingesting too much morphine and I had a serious porn addiction. What immediately grabbed me about its sequel, however, was its foundation in the Steamworks system. It's so simple to download and install mods, and while it's technically limited to ten active at any one time, it's quite easy to combine mods in the GUTS editor. As of the end of 2013, I really have no idea why any developer wouldn't want this implemented in their gaming environment. It extends playability by an infinite margin, and the only excuse I could think of from "big-time" publishers is that they really couldn't give a♥♥♥♥♥♥if people play their game - they only care about sales. (Insert TORtanic joke here.) But okay, enough soapboxing. Is it worth buying? If you're even remotely intrigued by the isometric hack-n-slash model, this game is a godsend (remark about religion). It's visceral, bloody, fast-paced, and there are so many different ways to play. I don't remember how many vanilla classes there are, but if you get off your soggy♥♥♥♥♥for two seconds you can find about twenty new classes in the workshop. There is so much to offer in this package, and you should buy it. 10/10 would play again

												I was headed towards a dungeon to complete a quest, ended up exploring the whole map, killed all the mobs, searched for the golden key to open the golden chest, went through a random portal which reserved me a side mission and finally started the dungeon. Seriously you won't see the time pass in this game, there is a lot to do. Pros:-Interesting bosses/monsters.-Complex itemization (many stats, enchantments, etc).-Multiple things to do (quests (dungeons, secret rooms, bosses), sidequests (mazes, mini bosses, etc) and other random stuff to do (fishing, gambling,etc). -Fun game to play with friends (if you're playing with multiple friends, play on elite or else it will be too easy).-Good combat system. In general, you can't simply spam click to clear mobs, the game pushes you to dodge abilities, manage your mana pool and react to different scenarios (use abilities to trap big guys, use your escape ability to..well escape,etc). Cons:-The story is bad, this is definietly not the game to play for its story. To be honest, I stopped caring about the story very early on.-Can get a bit repetitive. -Okay character custimization (character creation allows you to play very little with your character's features).8/10, great game to pick up when it goes on sale.

Posted: February 6, 2014
												WARNING- I have only played up to part way through act 2 of this game, but I have experience with all classes. I have not played the multiplayer.If you like ARPGs, you have probably already bought this game, so do not need to to recommend it to you. I don't. For what it's worth, Torchlight II is much better than it's predecessor, consisting of better, meatier combat as well as multiplayer and better difficulty. As an ARPG, it is near perfection, but as a game I find it somewhat lacking. Weapons like the shotgun and cannon could be meatier, and fighting with a melee character seems to lack impact. The game attempts to seem open world, but considering that I would have to clear out every area simply to keep up with levels, it misses the point entirely. In my opinion, the point of open world is that things are OPTIONAL- you could explore the nearby cave, or you could not. Removing that basically makes the concept useless. Mobility is done well, with dodging a powerful blow feeling very satisfying and fun, however there are some attacks that simply curve around to hit me again, removing the satisfaction. Bosses are similarly very satisfying, but also very dangerous and difficult to avoid- with a great feeling when you beat them.The skill system is not innovative, but generally well done- nothing more to say here. The dark music provides an interesting contrast to the cartoony art style, but I feel that the story simply isnt dark enough to fully support that contrast. However, most of the problems mentioned before are nitpicking, and the main game is stellar for its genre.If you like ARPGs, you will love this game, but it wont turn you onto the genre if you hate them.

Posted: June 11, 2014
												Torchlight II is an incredible action RPG in the top-down, point-and-click style of Diablo. Having played both Diablo III and this game, I must say that I found Torchlight II preferable. Many call it "Diablo with guns" but Torchlight II is much more than that. The handy pet system gives you both a battle companion and a courier, carrying your unwanted loot back to town and selling it automatically. The extend of character customization permitted is also much greater than in Diablo. The combat feels much less detached and more engaging, which is a welcome tweak. The greatest advantage of Torchlight II is that you don't have to be constantly connected to the internet to play. You can play solo offline and even play co-op over LAN. In that regard, Torchlight II is much more respectful of you as a customer.

While I feel that the trees lack a bit of focus and there is little to force a player to branch out from a few core skills, it beats the system in Diablo 3 which replaces character building with a linear path. Posted: January 17, 2016
												I stayed away from TL2 for a long time, fearing that it'd be nothing more than a mindless hack and slash.  In ways that's exactly what it is - it's been called 'what Diablo III should have been', but there is some strategy here.  The choices you make in how to equip your character do matter, and the game itself is enjoyable.There's no sandbox world here, though so far it seems large enough.  Basic gameplay consists of undertaking quests with your hardy pet companion, beating the snot out of whoever gets in your way, stealing their loot and getting rewarded for it.  Overall you're chasing after a bad guy called the 'Alchemist' who I'll assume wants to do bad guy things.  I haven't played Torchlight, which makes me feel like I'm missing a little something of the plot - but not enough to affect my enjoyment of the game.Your pet....is awesome, and probably one of the best companions/allies I've ever had in any RPG ever.  I chose a cat, and he just wades into the thick of the melee.  In the demo version I gave him a spell and he sat back with me fireballing everything that looked at us funny.  Sometimes in battles I'd have to stand back to let my hit points recover.  My cat would literally claw his way out, tearing a hole through the enemies and I swear give me a look that said 'wuss.'Don't expect meaningful plot choices or a hundred subplots (though there are side missions.)  That said, if you want to kill some stress by wading into an army of ratlings/skeletons/spiders/politicians and coming out bloodied but unbowed, this game's for you.

Posted: December 20, 2013
												This is one of the better games available these days.  The variety of difficulty choices means that you can choose anywhere from a casual gaming experience to a fairly challenging one.  Its new game plus feature adds to this, increasing the available content to include more challenging dungeons and quests, and pushing the potential difficulty as far as one is willing to take it.There are a wide variety of items, and options for customizing them through enchanting or socketing ember so that you can build your character as you see fit. There are also a host of unique items, including class specific ones that tailor to the differing aspects of the different classes.Aside from different classes being available, each class has three sets of skills to choose from, allowing different kinds of playstyles. For example, one could make a tank-like Engineer, or, one could make a cannon-wielding ranged attacker as an engineer.Adding to the variety of class options, the multiplayer opens up new possible playstyles, allowing players to synergize their skills with other players.  Through teamwork, certain tasks that may have previously been too challenging alone as a particular build may be able to be conquered with help from others.And finally, beyond the basic storyline gameplay, there is the "map" system, allowing one to visit endless multitudes of dungeon types in the spirit of the original Torchlight.  These dungeons can be generated using special maps which can be purchased in the game, allowing one to choose what kind of dungeon, what level range it is, and what special effects are enabled, such as enemies dropping more money, enemies being more powerful, certain elements dealing extra damage, among other possibilities.  So for the people who like to play a game into the ground, Torchlight II definitely is a good candidate for sinking time into.It's not without its flaws, of course, but there's nothing game-shattering.  Load times can be a little long between new areas at times.  Depending on the difficulty one has chosen, some enemies may be able to instantly kill the player with certain attacks(much like Diablo II enemies on the Hell difficulty).  Also, it's difficult to tell exactly what a skill will do, or how useful it will be, until you've had the opportunity to play around with it. There is a skill reset system to help deal with this, but you can only reset the last 3 skill points you have spent.  There is very little else wrong with it aside from those problems.Finally, the possibilities from mods allow you to change basically anything, even the player limit for multiplayer.  There's not much to say about this, but it's still a major feature of the game.  If you enjoy modding your games, Torchlight II is a fine candidate.I highly recommend Torchlight II to everyone.  It's easily a 9/10, one could play this game for hundreds of hours per class, or more.  Hardcore mode, new game plus, random dungeons, gear progression...Lots of replay value.

Posted: May 10, 2015
												Did you enjoy the first Diablo and Diablo II? Do you revel in the wholesale slaughter of anything in your way? Have you ever wondered what happens when you cross WoW-esque graphics with Diablo's grimdark setting?If you answered yes to any or all of these, I highly suggest you check out Torchlight II. As you can expect, this is the sequal to Torchlight, and basically the hero from the previous story ended up going slightly... umm... well, he needs to be stopped now. So please exterminate with extreme prejeduce and... oh, right, please don't go nuts yourself so we have to send someone else after you next. Sound familiar? Well, it probably should, since a good chunk of the team that did D2 left Blizzard and worked on this game. I personally feel that it is a more natural successor to D2 than D3 was, but that's a more personal opinion. So, enough gushing, let's get down to the brass tacks. You've got four classes: Embermage (glass canon caster), Outlander (think Ranger), Berserker (melee brute class), and Engineer (Tankiest tank that ever tanked). Each class has their own skill trees that you can progress down. Skill resets are rare and come in the form of potions that cannot be purchased, they must be found by killing extremely powerful opponents. You can, however, reset your last choice fairly easily, if you made a mistake on that one skill selection. However, honestly... there are no *bad* choices, only a matter of what you want to do.There are no class-restricted weapons or armor (barring class-specific legendaries), so you can have an Engineer dual-wielding pistols or wielding a staff if you want. However, certain class skills only function with certain weapon classes or gear combinations. Typically, you plan out a 'build', or find one online that you think you might like, and work toward it. Or you can do what I do and just play around with the skills until you find something that fits your play style. There are several difficulty settings, and the game is generally forgiving of mistakes. Unless you choose Hardcore mode, death is a very minor inconvenience, leading to a game which is very accepting of a casual playstyle. Your pet is another topic I would like to touch on. Not simply additional damage like your Merc was in D2, it has its own inventory and can cary trash loot and even run it back to sell for you while you continue on slaughtering things. You very rarely ever need to 'town portal' back because your pet handles all necessary transactions. In addition, your pet can learn spells that it will then cast appropriately. Yes, your pet can learn a Silence spell which it will then spam when it is in combat. Your pet's sell mechanic and the 'Charge' system both strongly encourage a 'forward momentum' style of playing, encouraging you to charge bravely forward rather than hesitating and hanging back, rewarding players for heroically charging into the thick of things. Oh, one last thing. It's now SteamOS compatible, meaning Linux compatible, for all those penguins who are looking to get their Diablo fix in without having to use WINE or PlayOnLinux. Personally, I love it. Even with the color palette that it uses, it still keeps that grimdark atmosphere and isn't afraid to poke fun at itself. There's also tons of easter eggs to find that will keep any true nerd laughting until dawn. But don't take my word for it, try it for yourself. Worst case, you spent money you might have used to go get a cup of coffee. Best case, you find the game as entertaining as I do.

Posted: June 26, 2014
												Best ARPG I've played to date. Why?- Casual gamer Friendly!- Although there is, what may seem at first, a limited number of classes the skill selection makes for at least 3 or 4 different sub-variations for each class. Replay value is great, although leveling is a test of patience. Capping taking roughly 2 complete playthroughs.- Graphics are not as hard on the average CPU that us mortals can afford. I prefer stylized graphics over realistic graphics because they are never out of style or look dated like most other 3D games.- It offers an Endgame consisting of Mapworks, a tool that allows you to run random dungeons of a level of your choosing (up to 105), and Tarroch's Tomb, a relentless 10 wave gauntlet that drops loot every wave you beat but disappears if you die (Wave 1 comprised of lvl 100 enemies and wave 10 of lvl 199 enemies).- The loot system actually feels FAIR!!! *coughs* Diablo III *coughs*- Moddability adds heaps to the game including a difficulty increase and class changes that increase replay value. Downside is modded game saves are different than stock and you can only play with people that have the same mods. Items can not be crossed from modded to unmodded.- If you get bored or just want to test limits you can duplicate items for money or utility by using a stash and save file manuever. You could also use console to spawn items but you will be labeled as a cheater. The ability to do these cheats adds a lot to the experienced of a gamer that is NOT HARDCORE. Casual gamers need to be catered to too.The only real downside I found was the relentlessness when making ability choices. MARK MY WORDS: You cannot respec more than the last 3 abilities you leveled or chose. This means you must level up a character from scratch to try a different build and will probably have to make 2 almost identical characters to fix a stupid choice mistake you made on your first try at a class. Some people love this feature but I believe it would be better if you could just have 2 sub-class slots like you have in WoW or if you could get an option to reset points after completing the game. Just my 2 cents.Please buy this and enjoy.

Posted: May 10, 2015
												Did you enjoy the first Diablo and Diablo II? Do you revel in the wholesale slaughter of anything in your way? Have you ever wondered what happens when you cross WoW-esque graphics with Diablo's grimdark setting?If you answered yes to any or all of these, I highly suggest you check out Torchlight II. As you can expect, this is the sequal to Torchlight, and basically the hero from the previous story ended up going slightly... umm... well, he needs to be stopped now. So please exterminate with extreme prejeduce and... oh, right, please don't go nuts yourself so we have to send someone else after you next. Sound familiar? Well, it probably should, since a good chunk of the team that did D2 left Blizzard and worked on this game. I personally feel that it is a more natural successor to D2 than D3 was, but that's a more personal opinion. So, enough gushing, let's get down to the brass tacks. You've got four classes: Embermage (glass canon caster), Outlander (think Ranger), Berserker (melee brute class), and Engineer (Tankiest tank that ever tanked). Each class has their own skill trees that you can progress down. Skill resets are rare and come in the form of potions that cannot be purchased, they must be found by killing extremely powerful opponents. You can, however, reset your last choice fairly easily, if you made a mistake on that one skill selection. However, honestly... there are no *bad* choices, only a matter of what you want to do.There are no class-restricted weapons or armor (barring class-specific legendaries), so you can have an Engineer dual-wielding pistols or wielding a staff if you want. However, certain class skills only function with certain weapon classes or gear combinations. Typically, you plan out a 'build', or find one online that you think you might like, and work toward it. Or you can do what I do and just play around with the skills until you find something that fits your play style. There are several difficulty settings, and the game is generally forgiving of mistakes. Unless you choose Hardcore mode, death is a very minor inconvenience, leading to a game which is very accepting of a casual playstyle. Your pet is another topic I would like to touch on. Not simply additional damage like your Merc was in D2, it has its own inventory and can cary trash loot and even run it back to sell for you while you continue on slaughtering things. You very rarely ever need to 'town portal' back because your pet handles all necessary transactions. In addition, your pet can learn spells that it will then cast appropriately. Yes, your pet can learn a Silence spell which it will then spam when it is in combat. Your pet's sell mechanic and the 'Charge' system both strongly encourage a 'forward momentum' style of playing, encouraging you to charge bravely forward rather than hesitating and hanging back, rewarding players for heroically charging into the thick of things. Oh, one last thing. It's now SteamOS compatible, meaning Linux compatible, for all those penguins who are looking to get their Diablo fix in without having to use WINE or PlayOnLinux. Personally, I love it. Even with the color palette that it uses, it still keeps that grimdark atmosphere and isn't afraid to poke fun at itself. There's also tons of easter eggs to find that will keep any true nerd laughting until dawn. But don't take my word for it, try it for yourself. Worst case, you spent money you might have used to go get a cup of coffee. Best case, you find the game as entertaining as I do.

												tl:drScore 7.2/10Pros:- Smooth animations- environment is nice to look at- a nice amount of builds to try out- doesn't feel like a grindCons:- barely any end game- items are not impactful- story is generic and bland during some areasTorchlight 2 is a fast-paced action multiplayer role playing game, similar to diablo 3. It has a colourful art style with smooth animations and 'click to move' movement. Torchlight 2 greatly improves on its predecessor Torchlight 1 through more gameplay options and content however still has some problems such as the lack of endgame due to the improved but still few build paths. In Torchlight 2, the aim is to stop 'the alchemist' from taking over the land in which you must complete a series of 'acts' which all include a large amount of dungeons and maps which are randomnly generated. The story however will only take a few hours to complete on easy difficulty but will be increasingly challenging the higher the difficulty. After you complete the story you are given the option to replay it at a higher difficulty or enter the 'clockwork' which is like a HUB where you choose various dungeons to clear and recieve rarer and stronger loot to upgrade your character. Overall the story is interesting and gives a sense of urgency to the player and will provide entertainment for a couple of hours until you complete it.However in Torchlight 2 the story is not its main focus, but rather its combat and rewards for completing dungeons. Torchlights combat is smooth, flashy and makes grinding fun due to its fast-paces and simple design. 3 Skills builds exist for all classes in which you can only undo up to your 5th choice making choosing your skills an important decision. Stat build also exist which improve your general strength. Rewards are recieved by killing monsters  which will drop gold, potions and items. Items come in various rarities with rarer items being stronger which you can upgrade by inserting gems (also dropped by monsters). The mentioned drops can also be found in chests found across the maps. In total the combat system is great and but lacks variety and the items dropped dont have much of a power up feel.Overall Torchlight 2 is a fun game to play while it lasts due to its great combat and beautiful artstyle. This is also supported by its multiplayer compatability and various skill options allowing for customisation of your character. This however does not last long due to its lacklustre end game which grows full and boring relatively quickly (yes, there are mods available but even they dont last very long and gameplay is in all intents and purposes the same). This leads to the final score for this game which is a 7.2/10 and can improve by increase end game content, more variety in skills and classes and more impactful drops

												I honestly couldn’t believe it at first, but Torchlight II is indeed a massive improvement over the original. I can’t tell you how it compares to Diablo or other Diablo clones, but I can tell you it’s an action RPG that trounces its predecessor in terms of variety and breadth of content.At its base TII has you doing the same things as in the original Torchlight, but Runic Games seems to have done everything it could to make grinding for look more exciting with more places to go, more interesting classes, and more abilities to unlock.Instead of just running around in one town, one main dungeon, and a bunch of extra random dungeons, TII gives you an actual world to explore, split into several environments, each with a main and side dungeons as well as its own visual identity. The first thing I noticed about TII in videos was probably that it had a distinctly different and livelier color palette than the first game. TII looks fresher and a lot more aesthetically pleasing than the first game pretty much just due to better art direction. The first two areas in particular -- a steppe inhabited by monks, and a snowy mountainside, really helped draw me into the game.All TII’s new classes seem to be interesting departures from the norm. In the original Torchlight I ended up picking the class that felt most familiar to me which was the warrior/tank dude. The closest thing in TII is the Berserker which I ended up enjoying a lot more. Yeah Berserkers still just tank everywhere, but the added focus on critical hits, their berserker meter and weapons like claws instead of swords and shields makes playing the class more interesting in my opinion.TII’s sound design also creates a great sense of tactile feedback. Not only does the impact of landing hits in combat sound satisfying, but even the menu interface feels and sounds better when you’re assigning upgrade points and unlocking abilities. I think it helps drive home a sense of real craftsmanship that reminds you TII was indeed made by professional game developers.The best thing Runic did to help get people into TII was creating its excellent demo, which by itself I found to be pretty addicting. It’s basically the first area -- the steppe, stopping after the completion of the first main quest. And even afterwards you can still just mess around in that area which is what I did for a while before buying the game. Once you do you can carry your progress over.TII also adds a New Game+ in which you loop your old character back through the game with enemies leveled higher. You can do this and have enemies level ever higher five times (for a total of six runs through the game). You can keep looping infinitely after that but enemies won’t get any stronger. TII also has multiplayer but I’ve actually only done solo so far.Lastly, TII has been reported to be able to run on integrated graphics, though I can’t confirm this 100 percent.$20 might be a lot for an indie game, but after learning how much content and variety was packed into TII, $20 feels like an excellent price for it.

Alas, I got back into Torchlight 2 and hoped for a fresh start. This game, initially, made me hesistant because of its cartoony artstyle since I was used to the Dark Fantasy type worlds of POE and D3. But, eventually I started to play  and got over that fact. The gameplay was enjoyable. For example, I enjoyed the fact we could distribute attributes early on and start to specialize in a type of skill set. But what got me hooked on this game was the Loot System and how it was so rewarding to defeat challenging dungeon bosses as well as get great Uniques and Legendaries. Plus, the environment and the side missions, like phase portals, were so unique and everchanging compared to other ARPGs. Posted: February 2, 2014
												If you aren't familiar with Torchlight, it's okay. You chose a class, killed lots of bad guys, and saved the day while loot fell from the sky. Nothing atypical of your classic dungeon crawler. However, everything it did, it did right. Itemization, drop rates, skill sets, and combat were just a joy to experience. The biggest downside was that I wanted to play with my friends, but I couldn't because it was single player only. This was everyone's biggest complaint.Fast forward to Torchlight 2 - Runic delivered. Everything that made Torchlight so polished was implemented into Torchlight 2. Only now, there's the addition of multiplayer just like the players wanted. In fact, you can play alongside 5 friends simultaneously.The graphics have been updated significantly from Torchlight. Lighting is improved, character models are sharper and more detailed. Weapons look fantastic and the animations are well done. Characters move fluently and quickly compared to other dungeon crawlers, so it may take some getting used to. All in all, it looks great. Mind you, this graphic style is very different from Diablo 3, but given the budget difference between the old Blizzard and new Blizzard, it does the job just fine.But who plays these games for the graphics alone? The loot is where the money is (pun intended). Torchlight 2 does that better than most on the market. There are myriad upgrades as you level, which include set items and socket pieces. This is not your dumbed down core stat itemization either. There are so many builds that work in Torchlight 2, and the items/set bonus tailor to your playstyle. If you want strong pets, farm gear with +pet/minion speed, get gems with +attack power for pets, etc. If you want to focus on ranged, they have ranged bonus sets, gems with +% ranged damage.You truly get the sense that your character is getting stronger as you level and you can tailor the gear to your personal build. That's what makes this game so much fun.To top it off, you don't have to spend 25-30 hours farming for an upgrade to your character at max level (or as you level). The good drops are very fair (some would argue too easy), however the upgradable items for your specific class or build may still take adequate time to achieve.Don't like auction houses to make your characters stronger? Me either. Torchlight 2 has no economy, which means no botters, no 3rd party messages, no WTS threads. You want an item? Play with 5 people and you'll see the community is willing to share with one another. Your in game gold is still used for enchanting items, buying from the gambler (have a chance to get very rare items), and buying various potions/scrolls/spells etc.I can go on about this game but it's a game you should definitely try if you are a fan of the genre. You will not be disappointed, and if you aren't into the online thing there is no "online only" requirement to enjoy this masterpiece of a game. Plus, at $20, it's a steal.

Posted: September 27, 2015
												This is one game that begs for DLC. Only three classes? You've got to be kidding me. That said, onto the good points. This is like Diablo 2, with a few good ideas tacked on, and placed in a fully 3D world. You'll have to forgive the DIablo comparisons, but this game warrants them: it was made by several ex-Diablo Blizzard crew members, and the polish shows. This is about the most comprehensively fun aRPG I have played since the release of D2. Do I like it better than Grim Dawn? Hell yes. Do I like it better than Path of Exile? Well, kinda. Yes, but the price point on Path sells it better; though in my mind, this is a more polished product. Do I like it better than D2? It follows in the same footsteps, so it is a more modern, updated version at its heart.I must at least add that for the price tag, it is the most fun "Diablo-like" I have played in about 5+ years, and could easily handwrestle the latest Blizzard release, Diablo 3 if it had tacked on more DLC. The endgame content on this, unfortunately, shortened my journey somewhat. The story is miles above the first Torchlight, and feel more coherent. Here, I feel a sense of *fighting* baddies, making my journey more meaningful. In the last game, everything seemed like an excuse to slay everything around me. This game  reverses the flow, putting plot first, and then allows the killing to begin in sequence, as the game world opens up. No more swimming for a portal that leads into an ever-downward dungeon. Here, there are separate areas, and new ideas, including some not present in D3, and certainly a better skill system than the latter. The first game was a nice time-waster. This one ties that problem up with a new plot, and several better ideas. I still think there should be DLC packs. This game calls for at least 3 more classes, to add online variety, and inspire players to frequent it more often. The narrative is well-done. The gameplay has a few twists on par with D3's treasure goblins. Visuals and art, check: graphics are top-notch. Audio is sufficient, nothing lacking, plenty of variety, no critical mistakes. Everything has an emphatic and crisp thump to it, and objects and fighting have loud *clangs,* and sound realistic, as well as sufficiently solid. Something Path of Exile lacks, I'm afraid. Collision detection is not finicky, like the latter, either. If anything, the only near miss is that emphatic lack of end-game content, along with replay value; easy levelling up to cap; and the few, uninspiring classes that would have been fixed with a shiny bit of DLC.At the time of release, this would have been a 9.5/10. At this point, I feel safer giving it an 8/10, as it is fun, polished, and has variety. Time will tell whether Torchlight supports an online community, and is willing to expand open its gameplay to more modes and challenges. Not in this release, I'm afraid. One thing is for certain: I will be first in line waiting for Torchlight 3. Let's hope for future news! Cheers. :D

Posted: December 1, 2013
												I honestly couldn’t believe it at first, but Torchlight II is indeed a massive improvement over the original. I can’t tell you how it compares to Diablo or other Diablo clones, but I can tell you it’s an action RPG that trounces its predecessor in terms of variety and breadth of content.At its base TII has you doing the same things as in the original Torchlight, but Runic Games seems to have done everything it could to make grinding for look more exciting with more places to go, more interesting classes, and more abilities to unlock.Instead of just running around in one town, one main dungeon, and a bunch of extra random dungeons, TII gives you an actual world to explore, split into several environments, each with a main and side dungeons as well as its own visual identity. The first thing I noticed about TII in videos was probably that it had a distinctly different and livelier color palette than the first game. TII looks fresher and a lot more aesthetically pleasing than the first game pretty much just due to better art direction. The first two areas in particular -- a steppe inhabited by monks, and a snowy mountainside, really helped draw me into the game.All TII’s new classes seem to be interesting departures from the norm. In the original Torchlight I ended up picking the class that felt most familiar to me which was the warrior/tank dude. The closest thing in TII is the Berserker which I ended up enjoying a lot more. Yeah Berserkers still just tank everywhere, but the added focus on critical hits, their berserker meter and weapons like claws instead of swords and shields makes playing the class more interesting in my opinion.TII’s sound design also creates a great sense of tactile feedback. Not only does the impact of landing hits in combat sound satisfying, but even the menu interface feels and sounds better when you’re assigning upgrade points and unlocking abilities. I think it helps drive home a sense of real craftsmanship that reminds you TII was indeed made by professional game developers.The best thing Runic did to help get people into TII was creating its excellent demo, which by itself I found to be pretty addicting. It’s basically the first area -- the steppe, stopping after the completion of the first main quest. And even afterwards you can still just mess around in that area which is what I did for a while before buying the game. Once you do you can carry your progress over.TII also adds a New Game+ in which you loop your old character back through the game with enemies leveled higher. You can do this and have enemies level ever higher five times (for a total of six runs through the game). You can keep looping infinitely after that but enemies won’t get any stronger. TII also has multiplayer but I’ve actually only done solo so far.Lastly, TII has been reported to be able to run on integrated graphics, though I can’t confirm this 100 percent.$20 might be a lot for an indie game, but after learning how much content and variety was packed into TII, $20 feels like an excellent price for it.

Posted: December 10, 2015
												Coming from somebody that did play Diablo 2 back in the day (and wasn't as fond of it as other people), this game takes the typical frustrating aspects of that game and throws them out the window. While it's possible that Diablo 3 does some of these things as well, I'm afraid I haven't played that game yet. First, you can load up your pet with unwanted loot and send it back to town while in the middle of a dungeon to sell for you. Generally returning after two minutes. You can even have it purchase stuff in town for you, like potions or scrolls. It's so nice to not have to constantly port back to town to empty out my inventory. You also don't have to click on gold to pick it up. You just have to walk over it. I may never play Diablo 2 again after getting used to such a nice feature. You get a hotbar for skills. You don't even need to have potions take up space on it because pressing Z or X automatically uses your best healing or mana potion. So I can press 1 for a firestorm, press 2 for fire pillars, press 3 to summon a ghost, etc. It kinda feels like playing an MMO. You can find ambiguous spells on any character that you can have four of equiped at any time, offering some variety into your gameplay. Like a spell that summons a horde of zombies, or a simple fireball, or a passive buff to your EXP and gold earned. The really cool part is that your pet also gets four spell slots and will use any spells automatically when you get into a fight and they're off cooldown. I have my pet set to summon two hordes of zombies AND some skeleton archers, with a passive spell that increases his damage and shortens the time it takes for him to get back from town. There's so much this game does right that it makes me kinda disappointed that the devs have moved on to other projects and don't plan to update Torchlight 2 anymore. But still, the game has easy intigration built in for the modding community. Totally recommended.

												This is a great sequel to the original. It feels like a v2.0 in the Torchlight series, but a few things didn't live up to my expectations. Firstly, since the original was single player only, I was hoping they would have carried over the original 3 classes and add 2+ more. Instead they created 4 new classes that mix and match skills from the original 3 play styles; none of which really grabbed me other then the Embermage. Secondly, plot wise (not a spoiler) the original heroes from the first game are NPCs in this one and you must kill one of them; this plot development doesn't sit well with me. Lastly, much of the plot development is still easily miss-able since they don't take you out of of in-game except for transitioning between Acts. For me, the ideal sequel for Torchlight would have been to include the original 3 classes and add a few new ones and make the main villain NOT one of the original 3 characters. Also, I would have liked to see them integrate the original story, enemies, and locations into this multiplayer iteration.These are all just small things that irk me a little. The gameplay is still as satisfying as the original and definitely a worthy entry in the ARPG genre. I can definitely recommended Torchlight II simply based on what you get for the price.(P.S. OFFLINE MODE FTW!)

Posted: December 20, 2013
												This is one of the better games available these days.  The variety of difficulty choices means that you can choose anywhere from a casual gaming experience to a fairly challenging one.  Its new game plus feature adds to this, increasing the available content to include more challenging dungeons and quests, and pushing the potential difficulty as far as one is willing to take it.There are a wide variety of items, and options for customizing them through enchanting or socketing ember so that you can build your character as you see fit. There are also a host of unique items, including class specific ones that tailor to the differing aspects of the different classes.Aside from different classes being available, each class has three sets of skills to choose from, allowing different kinds of playstyles. For example, one could make a tank-like Engineer, or, one could make a cannon-wielding ranged attacker as an engineer.Adding to the variety of class options, the multiplayer opens up new possible playstyles, allowing players to synergize their skills with other players.  Through teamwork, certain tasks that may have previously been too challenging alone as a particular build may be able to be conquered with help from others.And finally, beyond the basic storyline gameplay, there is the "map" system, allowing one to visit endless multitudes of dungeon types in the spirit of the original Torchlight.  These dungeons can be generated using special maps which can be purchased in the game, allowing one to choose what kind of dungeon, what level range it is, and what special effects are enabled, such as enemies dropping more money, enemies being more powerful, certain elements dealing extra damage, among other possibilities.  So for the people who like to play a game into the ground, Torchlight II definitely is a good candidate for sinking time into.It's not without its flaws, of course, but there's nothing game-shattering.  Load times can be a little long between new areas at times.  Depending on the difficulty one has chosen, some enemies may be able to instantly kill the player with certain attacks(much like Diablo II enemies on the Hell difficulty).  Also, it's difficult to tell exactly what a skill will do, or how useful it will be, until you've had the opportunity to play around with it. There is a skill reset system to help deal with this, but you can only reset the last 3 skill points you have spent.  There is very little else wrong with it aside from those problems.Finally, the possibilities from mods allow you to change basically anything, even the player limit for multiplayer.  There's not much to say about this, but it's still a major feature of the game.  If you enjoy modding your games, Torchlight II is a fine candidate.I highly recommend Torchlight II to everyone.  It's easily a 9/10, one could play this game for hundreds of hours per class, or more.  Hardcore mode, new game plus, random dungeons, gear progression...Lots of replay value.

												Take Diablo, think it through to the end and add whatever you think is missing. What you get is Torchlight 2.The settings are more colorful and so are the characters. You play either as mage, berserk, ranger or - and that's something you don't see often - engineer. Which is giving the whole story some nice steam-punk elements.The engineer uses handheld cannons, heavy weapons and builds robots, which means that he is pretty much the modern take on your good-old necromancer (minus the romance and plus the sledgehammer).The story itself is pretty simple. The "alchemist" (the hero you played in Torchlight 1) turns mad, BBQs his former allies and seeks world domination the unfriendly way. Meaning: he doesn't really believe in free-speech or elections.You are sent after him to make him reconsider.Which makes Torchlight 2 basically a Diablo 2 with better graphics minus Lucifer and plus Steam-Punk. Also with pets, multiplayer support and Steam workshop.Do you REALLY need anything else to feel convinced?Okay, fine! It also contains the option to have a head-crab as a pet and the ability to catch mutated fish that turn your pet head-crab into an angry treasure chest, trying to eat you. There!

Posted: October 8, 2014
												Experience of playing as 2-handed engy on Veteran Act III: "wtf just hit me I'm dead"This game is good. From the soothing string music to humorous weapon descriptions, there is a lot to see and play.  Loot drops rate are just right. Game mechanics are tight and well done (aside from the armor system) You don't have to go crazy on grinding for a proper weapon. Unique-tier weapons look pretty cool and have great descriptions to boot. Their damage and stats also fit your requirements for reasonably long, unlike that one FPS where your purple-rarity gun does♥♥♥♥♥♥damage 2-3 levels later. Apples to oranges. I don't care.The inclusion of "Arcane Stats", where you can see your actual damage output, proc chances, actual armor after bonuses factor in, etc, is really, really useful. This helps a lot in planning your build, and you don't have to do convoluted calculations to find your optimum loadout, and try to figure out whether a particular bonus is additive, multiplicative, applied post-multiplication, blahblah.The UI is very well built, comparing gear is easy, organizing items is easy, weapon damage is listed in DPS (honestly, why the hell not).However, when it comes to the really-high difficulties (NG+ Veteran, NG Elite, Mapworks), the armor system starts to show some bad problems if you play a tanking class. Armor damage reduction is calculated point-by-point rather as a percentage. Meaning if you have 800 armor, you will reduce an incoming attack by 800 damage. To play a serious build during Elite NG++ levels, you will have to farm for damage reduction socketables if you plan on consistently not dying when a mob so much as breathes on you.To quote Cthon from the TL2 forums:"Armor is basically meaningless. Not only is it badly outscaled by monster damage, but its effectiveness is also reduced by any damage reduction you have. To be as charitable as possible to armor, it's reasonably effective early on before monster damage scaling really gets going. A player who only did the first playthrough and did not do mapworks or NG+ might not encounter very many situations where no feasible amount of armor makes a meaningful difference."^This applies to anything above normal difficulty.Again, nobody cares about the story. Play on veteran mode if you've played RPGs before, normal is kinda easy.

												I was headed towards a dungeon to complete a quest, ended up exploring the whole map, killed all the mobs, searched for the golden key to open the golden chest, went through a random portal which reserved me a side mission and finally started the dungeon. Pros:-Interesting bosses/monsters.-Complex itemization (many stats, enchantments, etc).-Multiple things to do (quests (dungeons, secret rooms, bosses), sidequests (mazes, mini bosses, etc) and other random stuff to do (fishing, gambling,etc). -Fun game to play with friends (if you're playing with multiple friends, play on elite or else it will be too easy).-Good combat system. In general, you can't simply spam click to clear mobs, the game pushes you to dodge abilities, manage your mana pool and react to different scenarios (use abilities to trap big guys, use your escape ability to..well escape,etc). Cons:-The story is bad, this is definietly not the game to play for its story. To be honest, I stopped caring about the story very early on.-Can get a bit repetitive. -Okay character custimization (character creation allows you to play very little with your character's features).8/10, great game to pick up when it goes on sale.

Posted: June 27, 2016
												(I try to be 100% honest in my reviews. Enjoy!)Torchlight II is an action/RPG/hack n' slash game set in an extremely colorful and fictional world. I played the first game on the Xbox and absolutely loved it, and in many ways, Torchlight II picks up the slack where the first game didn't.In terms of story, both gams are lacking. MINOR SPOILER: In the first game, one of the allies you make in the game injects himself with Ember and becomes the main bad guy. (I believe his name is the Alchemist.) In the sequel, the Alchemist returns and burns Torchlight, so you have to go and defeat him again. Along the way, you will find sidequests and bosses to fight that will help you level up so you can defeat the next boss, level up, defeat the next boss, etc. While this main seem boring and repetitive, in the eight hours I've played the game Torchlight II has never felt tedious or exhausting. (Only recently it has become slightly annoying due to enemies called Sandrats that are SO HARD TO KILL.) Other than that, the bosses always offer up a new spin and are just enough to keep you on your toes.Where Torchlight II shines from its predecessor is the revamped menus. It's so easy to find loot and determine if it's better than yours or not, find if weapons do more damage than the one you have, etc. You also have the ability to have two sets of weapons. (I prefer having a ranged set and a melee set, but do whatever you want if you buy this.) The customization of characters is fairly extensive, especially with the added pets you can have to help you. And I must say, the pets are EXTREMELY helpful.Other small fixes include better warning systems on Trapped Chests. (Fans of the first game will get what I mean,) as well as more mana abilites that will allow you to take out several enemies at once, and also some very wide open areas where you can free people from slave caravans, take on monsters, and if you're lucky, find a Phase Beast that will give you a Phase Portal. (Warning: Entering a Phase Portal will take you to a fairly challenging arena battle, but the loot is incredible.)My only complaint about Torchlight II, and this may just be a glitch for me, but recently I have been collecting loot that is WAY out of my level range. I don't know if I missed a couple of sidequests that would have pushed me to a higher level to get better equipment. I wouldn't think they would make the sidequests necessary for leveling up in the main quests, because they are supposed to be bonus things for XP and so on.10/10Better Than TorchlightFun And ChallengingMay Get RepetitiveMinor Leveling IssuesI hope this review helps you make your decision!

Posted: June 24, 2014
												I have always really enjoyed dungeon-crawling RPG's (diablo and the like) and so I am also a very harsh critic of them. To that point, I HATED Torchlight 1, but I am actually a big fan of Torchlight 2. More so than Diablo 3 (pre-Reaper of souls) and more so than dungeon siege 3.This game really did impress me though. The action is fast-paced and quite consistent as well. Gone is Torchlight 1's horrible scheme of 100 levels of same-dungeon-different-layout; now the game plays in more of an open world, where there are connected regions which have various side dungeons (and 'side-quests') within them. You can fill it all in and search for better drops or you can just move foward with the main questline if you like. I am also quite fond of the skill and ability systems. It is very reminiscent of Diablo 2, more so than the third. You can select which character stats to increase, as well as which skills to level up. You don't really have a skill 'tree' as you are free to select them at your own whim. However, there are 'ranks' for each skill which give you a bonus trait or added effects once you hit certain levels with each ability.All in all this game can be very addicting. The visuals and text can be a little too cartoon-y for my taste, but it is very easy to lose track of time while combing a new map or thrashing your way through a dungeon and it is fun to take the (short amount of) time to build your character. Plus there's multiplayer, so fun with a friend!

Posted: June 24, 2014
												I have always really enjoyed dungeon-crawling RPG's (diablo and the like) and so I am also a very harsh critic of them. To that point, I HATED Torchlight 1, but I am actually a big fan of Torchlight 2. More so than Diablo 3 (pre-Reaper of souls) and more so than dungeon siege 3.This game really did impress me though. The action is fast-paced and quite consistent as well. Gone is Torchlight 1's horrible scheme of 100 levels of same-dungeon-different-layout; now the game plays in more of an open world, where there are connected regions which have various side dungeons (and 'side-quests') within them. You can fill it all in and search for better drops or you can just move foward with the main questline if you like. I am also quite fond of the skill and ability systems. It is very reminiscent of Diablo 2, more so than the third. You can select which character stats to increase, as well as which skills to level up. You don't really have a skill 'tree' as you are free to select them at your own whim. However, there are 'ranks' for each skill which give you a bonus trait or added effects once you hit certain levels with each ability.All in all this game can be very addicting. The visuals and text can be a little too cartoon-y for my taste, but it is very easy to lose track of time while combing a new map or thrashing your way through a dungeon and it is fun to take the (short amount of) time to build your character. Plus there's multiplayer, so fun with a friend!

Posted: July 25, 2015
												Adequate, but not exceptional Diablo-esque.  While the first torchlight was diablo inspired, this is more like diablo 2, done softcore.  There are moments that will give you flashbacks to D2: fetishes in a jungle (no joke), (seemingly) endless deserts and sewers, and a barely-there plot.  Unfortunately, they toned down some of the best things about D2 and left some of the worst.  If you like this genre, it's definitely worth a go.The good:+ There are no bad skills.  Although there are absolutely a few exceptional skills for each class that are much better than the rest, all of the skills will get you through the game just fine.  There are typically two skills that you start with that will take you through the first playthrough.  Then there's a "better" skill that unlocks at 48, which will take you further.  Most of the middle skills are, well, middling.+ Classes are balanced.  I played through with all the classes, Beserker was the surprise favorite (great mobility, great damage, great damage mitigation, great healing, best endgame set, no obvious downside).  The engineer and embermage lag a bit, but not much.  Outlander is solid.  All classes were very viable, even if they played mostly the same (same utility skills in the same spots in the trees).+ Lots of fun little flourishes in some of the art.  Witches appear from a swirl of bats.  Werewolves hang from the rafters and drop down to say hi.+ Enchanting system is much better than T1, skull/eye/gems mimic D2's runes, gambling is actually fun.+ Pacing is mostly good.  A few slow parts, but overall fine.+ Mod scene has produced some very good things.  Not my thing, but it could be yours.+ Lots of achievements.The cons:- Loot.  You'd think this would be a plus; it's not.  Loot progression is fine for the first 20 levels (Act 1) with upgrades reasonably frequent and meaningful, then it hits a wall.  After 20, gear no longer really improves outside of the weapons getting bigger DPS numbers.  Most of the endgame sets don't even bother to have stats - seriously.  My first playthrough, I wore almost the same gear from act 2 till the end.  It's seriously that bad.  The problem is that there's a ton of useless modifiers (armor of all types), and only two or three modifiers that do anything...and those are mostly the +stat options.  Uniques are mostly mediocre; set bonuses are good in a couple cases, but mostly yawn-worthly; even the legendaries aren't that good.- You will only use one or two skills for any character.  Even the engineer - who you'd expect would be busy managing their creations - is just a hold-and-click.- The respec system is terrible.  You can refund your last three skills, except to test out a skill you typically need to put in 5-10 points to see how it behaves at different unlock levels.  The one saving grace is there are multiple respect mods and utilities which correct this without penalty (and you should plan on using one of them because they are essential to having any fun with this game).- Draw distance is far too close.  It's especially bad for ranged characters -- your shots will go much further than the edge of the screen, but won't actually hit anything because those mobs haven't been spawned in.- The luminous area in Act 2 can go eat a bag of.  It's the only area that resets if you die and res to town. (tip: don't res in town, res in the dungeon so you don't have to start over)The rest:* The Acts are not of uniform quality.  Act 2 is awful (endless dessert), Act 3 is quite good (best art, interesting quests), Act 1 is in-between, Act 4 feels tacked on but you can rush through it.* You can just res-get-two-hits-in-die-and-repeat to beat things (aka no hard gear/skill checks).TL;DR: it's no D2, but it's still kinda fun.  Don't expect the world from it and you'll have a good time.  The negative reviews are mostly spot on if you're on the fence.  I'd give it a 8/10 for the first playthrough or for someone new to the genre, 6/10 if you're a genre vet looking for something meaty (and honestly you'd probably be better off with POE).

Posted: January 2, 2013
												So, Torchlight II is the continuation of the Torchlight series released back in 2009 by Runic Games. This game is a sequel to the first Torchlight game made.Plot: The story is pretty simple and easy to follow, it was pretty memorable, it had memorable boss fights and references to other games that they put in such as Vyrax's tower and the Dragon Shrine, which is a huge reference to The Elder's Scrolls IV: Skyrim. The game in my opinion is quite entertaining, although it could be a little too short for some hardcore RPG players as looking at other games for example the Diablo series and so, but personally I also agree that the story itself is a little too short, even though there are things that allowed you to just continue playing this game over and over again.Gameplay and Multiplayer: With multiplayer added to the Torchlight universe compared to the first game that didn't have any elements of multiplayer, really did open up new windows for people to really play this game. Also with the addition of the games being mod-able, multiplayer has been as fun as ever since it is also a drop-in/drop-out type which does not affect the storyline whatsoever, but with more players in the game the hostile enemies will get a little tougher which could be hard for some people, but in general it does not affect the single player gameplay at all.Visuals: One word-- "Polished". The game looks great and really amazing. It was detailed, beautiful and fun to look at even if they were cartoonish and not as realistic as many of the games out there, they are really well done. As for the cut-scenes, they still hold back the elements from Torchlight 1, which retained the uniqueness and credibility of Torchlight, which I believe this game is perfect for most audiences that enjoy games that maybe aren't too realistic. Audio: The OST is made by Matt Uelmen, the composer and sound designer of the Diablo series, also joined with Max Schaefer, the same people who made the music for the first Torchlight game. Although the soundtrack really differs in theme from the soundtrack of the Diablo series, they did a really amazing job of implementing the country music themes which gave it a distinctly different sound from the "Tristram" them of Diablo which made it great. They also did an amazing job in this part as they recorded over 200 live takes using a twelve string guitar alongside with many other instruments. The voice acting in this game casted many veteran voice actress and actors such as Lani Minella and so on who performed many of the voices in-game.Reception: This game scored slightly more than the original Torchlight, which most of the reviews received were very favorable. On review sites such as Metacritics, this game attained an overall score of 88 out of 100 based on many reviews from 65 professional gaming critics worldwide which is an amazing score. Would you buy this game? Many RPG players would probably think that this game will just be like the first Torchlight and therefore result in a quick 'hiatus' from playing the game due to the repetitive nature of the game, however this is different. The developers themselves released tools for the players to be able to mod the game as they please, and people who join any multiplayer servers with mods on them will be able to access the mods freely, which leaves the game always moldable and playable in its own unique manners all the time.

Although there are absolutely a few exceptional skills for each class that are much better than the rest, all of the skills will get you through the game just fine.  There are typically two skills that you start with that will take you through the first playthrough.  Then there's a "better" skill that unlocks at 48, which will take you further.  Most of the middle skills are, well, middling.+ Classes are balanced.  I played through with all the classes, Beserker was the surprise favorite (great mobility, great damage, great damage mitigation, great healing, best endgame set, no obvious downside).  The engineer and embermage lag a bit, but not much.  Outlander is solid.  All classes were very viable, even if they played mostly the same (same utility skills in the same spots in the trees).+ Lots of fun little flourishes in some of the art.  Witches appear from a swirl of bats.  Werewolves hang from the rafters and drop down to say hi.+ Enchanting system is much better than T1, skull/eye/gems mimic D2's runes, gambling is actually fun.+ Pacing is mostly good.  A few slow parts, but overall fine.+ Mod scene has produced some very good things.  Not my thing, but it could be yours.+ Lots of achievements.The cons:- Loot.  You'd think this would be a plus; it's not.  Loot progression is fine for the first 20 levels (Act 1) with upgrades reasonably frequent and meaningful, then it hits a wall.  After 20, gear no longer really improves outside of the weapons getting bigger DPS numbers.  Most of the endgame sets don't even bother to have stats - seriously.  My first playthrough, I wore almost the same gear from act 2 till the end.  It's seriously that bad.  The problem is that there's a ton of useless modifiers (armor of all types), and only two or three modifiers that do anything...and those are mostly the +stat options.  Uniques are mostly mediocre; set bonuses are good in a couple cases, but mostly yawn-worthly; even the legendaries aren't that good.- You will only use one or two skills for any character.  Even the engineer - who you'd expect would be busy managing their creations - is just a hold-and-click.- The respec system is terrible.  You can refund your last three skills, except to test out a skill you typically need to put in 5-10 points to see how it behaves at different unlock levels.  The one saving grace is there are multiple respect mods and utilities which correct this without penalty (and you should plan on using one of them because they are essential to having any fun with this game).- Draw distance is far too close.  It's especially bad for ranged characters -- your shots will go much further than the edge of the screen, but won't actually hit anything because those mobs haven't been spawned in.- The luminous area in Act 2 can go eat a bag of.  It's the only area that resets if you die and res to town. (tip: don't res in town, res in the dungeon so you don't have to start over)The rest:* The Acts are not of uniform quality.  Act 2 is awful (endless dessert), Act 3 is quite good (best art, interesting quests), Act 1 is in-between, Act 4 feels tacked on but you can rush through it.* You can just res-get-two-hits-in-die-and-repeat to beat things (aka no hard gear/skill checks).TL;DR: it's no D2, but it's still kinda fun.  Don't expect the world from it and you'll have a good time.  The negative reviews are mostly spot on if you're on the fence.  I'd give it a 8/10 for the first playthrough or for someone new to the genre, 6/10 if you're a genre vet looking for something meaty (and honestly you'd probably be better off with POE).

Posted: February 16, 2013
												Torchlight II is another of my top games from 2012.  After 142+ hours, I have multiple characters (2 of which are in their first endgame) and alleged plans for another to play with family.  New Game+ still seems like too much content for me to bother with, but it's existence makes this a prime candidate to take if on a deserted island.The cooperative mode is the main draw over the prequel.  There were some sync issues that make me question the viability of playing hardcore mode online.  However, I live in the US and played on Elite difficulty with a guy from Germany without too many deaths I could blame on the network.For those who go overboard micromanaging their equipment stashes like myself, gem availability is also an improvement.  Players are encouraged to use gems immediately because they are plentiful and can no longer be upgraded.  If you don't have any equipment to use a gem then there's not much reason to keep it around.Another, perhaps questionable, improvement is the delayed access to procedurally generated maps.  Although my skills and loot rewards differed, I was initially disappointed at how my characters seemed to be travelling roughly the same environments.  Then I remembered that I never finished the first Torchlight because I focused on an endless supply of random dungeons.  Pushing them to the finale is a suitable reward.  I just wish the map templates weren't so strict and predictable.Overall, Torchlight II is pretty and it plays well.  I suggest placing a mobility skill on the right mouse button if one is available.  (For instance, I have a Berserker with Shadow Burst and an Outlander with Burning Leap.)  I'd also change the hotkey row to something resembling a 3x3 grid, but maybe that's just my own lack of typing skill.

Posted: January 3, 2014
												Torchlight II is an entertaining and rewarding Action-RPG for the most part, especially if you are more of a casual player. If you are a hardcore ARPG player however, the game may be a hit or miss for you. The game does what it is meant to do really well and it was well worth the price I payed. If it is on sale I'd recommend picking it up no doubt.As a hardcore player I have both positive and negative opinions on this title:PROS:- Satisfying combat.- Plenty of items and gear.- Friendly to casual players. - Randomly generated areas. - Unique and appealing graphics style.- Great soundtrack and sound effects.- Good Co-Op gameplay.- Save your progress anywhere anytime.- Decent side quests and challenges.- Character classes not locked to certain weapons or gear.- Mod supported.- Plenty of different enemies and areas.CONS:- Only 4 main classes.- Lackluster skill trees.- Unappealing, almost non-existing storyline. - Short completion time (for hardcore players).- Almost no voice acting.If you are experienced make sure to set your difficulty to a high one. I played through the game in two evenings with a friend on Normal which was a mistake from our side. If you are new Normal is fine, if you have kids who wants to play, this game is great for that audience. You can disable blood if that is an issue as well. This is not to be confused with TL2 only being a casual kids game. If you like a good storyline that immerses you further this game does not offer that. Especially when most of the characters doesn't even have voice acting. It was a let down for sure.If you are looking for a complex skillsystem this game does not offer that either. Surely there are skills and combinations that are more complicated but perhaps not from hardcore player's eyes. Since there are just a few skills to choose from, you won't have much choice early on since you unlock the skills as you level up. The skills themselves however can be leveled up individually to grant them greater powers and enhancements. It doesn't really compensate the simplicity and limitations however.If you are looking for a more casual Action-RPG with satisfying combat, exploration, loot, gear and unique look, this game is for you. You don't have to just be a casual gamer to play it but I feel it is aimed more towards this audience. The game does what it does very well if you don't consider the storyline and don't bother too much with a complex skill system. I'd still recommend it to hardcore players if you keep the previous in mind. The game has end-game maps/dungeons that you can play for greater rewards at high levels and you can have it set to a hard difficulty for the challenge as well. Other than that I didn't feel that the replay value was that good.For casual players = 8.5/10For hardcore players = 7.5/10

												An awesome game if you can get a friend or two to play it with. These kinds of games, to me, are only fun when you have others to play with. If not, they seem kind of empty and dull. One of my friends that I bought a copy for stopped playing after a short while and never got through the first half of Act 2. I played for a bit, but lost interest shortly after because of it. Online multiplayer is a coin toss as servers hosted are either private, specific mod enabled, or cheatery. However, the game itself is great. I played by myself for a bit and got to Act 3. There's a good variety of mobs and bosses. Also, the replay value of the game is decent too. The layout changes when you create a new character or re-roll the world making it seem pretty new. New landmarks appear or move around a bit. The items and shops are great in-game. The balance is pretty reasonable but can be broken by using certain items together. I had a lower level 20-ish ranged class with dual pistols that would roll over anything up until around the 40's because of certain sockets that were stacked thanks to being able to transfer items between characters. Hardcore mode and mods from the steam workshop fix this up pretty quick.If you don't mind playing solo, this game is great. It can be compared to Diablo 2 styled gameplay. The graphics are a bit more colorful and less grim, but the feeling is there. If you have some reliable friends to play with, you'd probably have a much better time and get to the fun bits that really start happening around the end of Act 2 and into Act 3.
