Posted: May 9, 2016
												Quick Summary: Torchlight 2 is a fun action RPG with gameplay very similar to Diablo 2 or the Incredible Adventures of Van Helsing. There is built in mod support for which you can download mods from the Steam workshop, and a ton of “end game” things like New Game + and Mapworks.After the events of the first Torchlight game, the Alchemist (one of the heroes) has been corrupted by an artifact he took from the first game’s villain, and is planning to do all sorts of awful stuff. It’s up to 4 new heroes to follow and stop him before he unleashes a demonic invasion. It’s a pretty generic story (very similar to Diablo 2) with a few cartoony cutscenes. Most of the plot comes from conversations with quest giver NPCs, as you’d expect in an action RPG.As mentioned earlier, the game is very similar in gameplay to Incredible Adventures of Van Helsing. You play in a third person isometric view and use your mouse buttons for attack/spell casting on hordes of monsters. Each class of character has 3 skill “tabs” but they aren’t conventional skill “trees” meaning none of the skills have prerequisites. You can also find scrolls that can be used to learn additional skills like healing or summoning spells. Interestingly, these scrolls can be used to teach skills to your “pet” (similar to like Katarina in the Van Helsing games). The pet can also be sent back to town to sell excess items, and provides a small presence in combat. Don’t count on the pet to do any real killing or tanking though (unlike Katarina). Anyone familiar with ARPG games will know how the randomly generated loot and levels work, and just like the first Torchlight game, there is a lot of socketable “ember” to be found. Ember is like the gems in Diablo 2, and can be added to equipment with sockets to provide bonuses like + damage or +% resistance (depending on if it goes into a weapon or an armor). There are a number of “unique” or “set” loot items as well as “legendaries” which are uber rare and can take a hundred hours of grinding to find. Your inventory stash is rather limited, but you do have the option to share items between characters.Pros:+Multiplayer co-op for the campaign, and the loot is individualized so don’t worry about someone stealing your item drops.+The game is pretty long (about 16 hours) and there is a lot to do, even after you beat the story. You can play the New Game + (start the game over with all your items and skills) or you can play the Mapworks, which randomly generates levels. You can only find the legendary items in New Game +.+For a game with so much content, the download size is remarkably small. It’s also not very hardware intensive, but the graphics are still pretty good.  You can also download player made mods from the steam workshop to mix things up even more.Cons:-The game can get very grindy, especially if you’re going for some of the Steam achievements.  Some of them (like selling 50k items to merchants) will likely take hundreds of hours playing. -The respec system is very limited. You can only reset the last 3 skill points you put in, so if you want to try different builds, you need to start a new character. You can use console commands to fully respec, but that marks your character as a cheater in online play.Overall the game is very good but by the time you finish the first playthrough you probably will want to take a break. I played the rather overpowered spell caster character and my fingers hurt by the end of the game. I didn’t really feel like going into New Game +. I can only imagine what it would be like playing through with a melee fighter that has to sit there swinging at each enemy. In comparison, I played through the Incredible Adventures of Van Helsing back to back with all 3 character classes (though that game was significantly shorter).

You can only reset the last 3 skill points you put in, so if you want to try different builds, you need to start a new character. You can use console commands to fully respec, but that marks your character as a cheater in online play.Overall the game is very good but by the time you finish the first playthrough you probably will want to take a break. I played the rather overpowered spell caster character and my fingers hurt by the end of the game. I didn’t really feel like going into New Game +. I can only imagine what it would be like playing through with a melee fighter that has to sit there swinging at each enemy. In comparison, I played through the Incredible Adventures of Van Helsing back to back with all 3 character classes (though that game was significantly shorter).

Posted: November 29, 2013
												Torchlight II is a spectical. Sent out as a response to the evergrowing Diablo III, Torchlight II not only improves on its predacessor, but comes to the forefront in the hack and slash adventure. Though, like EVERY game, it is not perfect. Torchlight  II suffers from issues that could have vastly improved the game.When you get into the universe of Torchligh, you are welcomed to a rather beautiful steampunk and "cartoony" world (as much  as I hate describing an art style with that word). When I use my abilities in a blaze of assorted colors, it is wonderful. The art style in this game contrasts a lot hack and slash / dungeon crawlers out there, like Diablo II, Diablo III and Path of Exile. There are four playable classes in the game, all with dynamic and unique abilites. However, there is not much room for experimentation with skill trees, mostly due to the fact that you have to use an exploit to get around this feature. WIth all the  skills usable in this game, it is a damn shame you can't have more freedom. Another feature is the pet system, which is essentially your ♥♥♥♥♥. Put a ton of stuff in his inventory to sell, or send him on a shopping spree! The loot tables in the game are also great. Torchlight II disregards the grindyness of Diablo III, and makes you want to get to the next level, or get new loot! The amount of great stuff that drops is spectacular, and I am so pleased when I defeat a boss to chant, "LOOT! LOOT! LOOT!" Not to mention, the end game is pretty good, with an option to go to the Mapworks, an area in which you can purchase dungeons, and go adventuring through them. OR, you can continue your experience with NG+. However, I did not care whatsoever for the story of Torchlight II. Generic, mythical story with uninteresting characters. Enough said. And honestly, who cares? That is not what you play the game for. Torchlight II is a real spectical - a great change to the formula of Diablo III. Torchlight strays away from making these games a job, and rather a fun game with enough strategy to be challenging. Not only that, but levels are interesting, varied, and creative. Beyond that, Torchlight II is available at $20, where as Diablo III is priced at $60! You will never get a deal like this anywhere else. Did I also mention if you don't like game mechanics, textures, etc, there is a great modding community? That should be enough of a steal for gamers.

												Not one to normally review games, but this one, this game fit everything I was looking for in an Action RPG. It has a comprehensive leveling system with unique skill trees for each of the four classes and four classic stats which power several categories of combat. My only real complaint is the lack of a respec. You are only able to remove the last three skill points you have spent. I found after three hours of slaying and looting that I had a grasp of what I wanted my particular character to do in terms of combat. As I looked at my skills and stats that I had dumped points into I realized I had a mish mash of points spread unevenly. 												Torchlight 2 is to Torchlight, the same way Diablo 2 was to Diablo. Except without the expansion, it still  shines, where as Diablo 2 required Lord of Destruction to really shine.Now Torchlight 2 literally builds upon Torchlight in pretty much every way. The story continues, with the same three heroes from the last game making obvious cameos, and even useful cameos, which is rare in games today, if you ask me.Torchlight 2 boasts 4 different classes. Posted: July 14, 2013
												Torchlight II is easily one of the best Action RPGs that you can play right now and that has been released in recent years. It also happens to be one of my all-time favorite games. With the FREE play event going on now through Sunday 1PM PST, you owe it to yourself to play this great Runic game and see why its so highly rated. One awesome feature is that you can play this game in Offline Mode, a great way to pass time when having internet issues. It contains great character classes, very fun skills to use, and so much shiny loot to pick up that your head will explode. Also don't forget about the fishing. :)It just gets better with the addition of Steam Workshop now that there is a great amount of content that has been converted and updated using this format. While it does suck that you can only run the game with a total of ten active mods, you can have steam workshop track and auto-update fifty mods in total.Thankfully, skilled users have become quite successful at releasing compilations that help bypass this limit and enhance your gaming experience with lots of active mods such as the fantastic work done by Bandit in his "Combine Them All" mod. :)Another great feature Runic added is that the game separates your original-stock and workshop-mod characters into different save folders and cloud saves. This makes it very easy for you to play your high level stock characters online with others for those purist out there. Then you restart your game in mod mode and play with your friends online using your modded characters. If you're modded toons are like mine, they will be custom classes such as "Necromancer" and "Warlock" from the SynergiesMOD by Salan or "Ninja" and "Ronin" from the Far East Pack by Zyph.I can recommend a nice list of workshop mods that play very well together and enhance your game even further once you have beaten the standard version of the game. It's what I use when playing online or offline to help me relax, unwind, and clear my head from design fatigue. One of these days I'll get around to posting them as a Collection in the Steam Workshop when I have more free-time between designing games. TIP: I highly recommend that if you play modded games on-line with your friends that you synch your game mods and the order they are loaded beforehand to eliminate most on-line problems. The easiest way we found to do this was share a zip file of all the mods we would use with a text file listing the mods priority when loading them if anybody joining didn't have them. We would not include large and popular mods such as SynergiesMOD, Far East Pack, and Enhanced Retex, but we would note the version number in the text file. There are a few mods that don't work well together or on-line, but we've been able to play the majority of them in different combinations as long as we followed this tip.TIP: While the Steam Cloud synch tends to do a good job overall, sometimes it can fail and override your local copy of your saved game with an outdated one from the Steam Cloud. What I've done is keep a secondary backup of my saved games so when that happens, I can easily replace the cloud copy with my current local backup. The default location for the Torchlight II saved games is at "My Documents\My Games\Runic Games\Torchlight 2\". You want to backup the "save" and "modsave" folders regularly especially if you play the game frequently in offline mode.Hopefully someday we will get a remastered HD version of the game but I will settle for Torchlight III. =)

												If you're a fan of Diablo 2, you'll be right at home with this fantastic RPG. Good quests, great inventory structure, pets you can send to town with excess loot and more. Posted: January 25
												Every once in a while, I love to smash everything and everyone in sight - then I turn to a something like Torchlight II. Hack & Slay is the name of the game, and it feels just as satisfying as the rich booty from those battles. The enemies and surroundings are diverse enough, and some bosses look relatively awesome. I say "relatively" because overall, the graphics have not aged well. On the other hand, the music is still excellent. Dialogues are short and do not involve any important decisions or moral dilemmas, which is an advantage because the voice acting is mostly sub-par. Grim Dawn is superior in this regard and managed to create a lot more depth of atmosphere (e.g. the Steampunk setting with fireweapons side by side with swords and maces is more plausible in a post-apocalyptic scenario - Torchlight does not bother with giving you that kind of background). Also, it is four years younger and has better graphics. If in doubt which one you should play, I would prefer Grim Dawn. Nevertheless, Torchlight II is well done, it offers consistently engaging gameplay and character progression as well as several options for you to keep on playing after finishing the main story. The feature that you can use your pet as a connection to town markets is not realistic, but innovative and conveniently saves your hero some annoyingly repetitive errands, which is why I make this honorary mention here. I recommend this game to fans of the genre and give it a 7/10 in this comparison group.

Posted: February 28, 2016
												Torchlight's actual storyline and most major quests can be completed in ~15-20 hours. However, the extra content that takes more grinding is the real meat of this game. Acquiring end-game loot to make yourself a raidboss is the final destination. My experience with this game is that at first it's quite disorienting, however with more gameplay it gets better, but also becomes very robotic . I do like the graphics and the storyline of the game as well as the variety of different settings and monsters you face. However, if you don't like grinding this game may not be for you. I would recommend this game if it's on sale, but if it were bought for full price I don't think it's worth it.I like the fact that you can Co-op, however in co-op worlds the max amount of players is 4 and whatever you accomplish in that co-op world isn't translated over to your singleplayer, so it's best to keep quests finished in singleplayer first. My impression of the community is that there's a bunch of super dedicated players and keep to themselves a lot and if you're not dedicated you can't break the ice with them. Another awesome feature is that the workshop really brings out a whole new environment for the game. Extra classes, extra abilities,the workshops are a must visit if you want to experience this game fully.Some downsides do include that the combat interface/system isn't explained at first and you're just dropped in a place and you're expected to know how to fight. Maybe a tutorial at first wouldn't hurt. With this being said, the learning curve isn't actually that great if you've played any RPG before. There are 4 basic stats each helping a certain feature and beneficial for certain classes.In summary, I think this game has some great features, the main storyline replayability isn't that high, but the workshops and the extra after the storyline quest grinding will be what you spend most of your time on. I rate this game a good 8/10 for $5.49, maybe lower if it's going for $21.99.
